dialogues.speaker: ON A YOUNG COUPLE KISSING
dialogues.text: on the beach. As the CAMERA GLIDES AROUND THEM, the MUSIC soars. CAMERA WIDENS and we realize we are watching the Young Co on a large Computer Screen and at the computer's keyboard writing the MUSIC we're hearing is MILES -- early thirtie boyish, shaggy in his T-shirt and khakis. The depth and tenderness of his composition belies his appearance. We a in: MILES’ L.A. HOUSE IN THE HOLLYWOOD HILLS Small and Spanish. It’s a December afternoon. Through the windows, we see the wind blowing olive trees in a courtya Miles continues to compose as we SEE his PRETTY GIRLFRIEN the b.g., talking on her cell as she gets dressed. An act no doubt. Over, we HEAR the VOICE OF A YOUNG ENGLISH WOMAN, IRIS. Iris' Voice is knowing and warm.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I have found almost everything ever written about love to be true. Shakespeare said, "Journeys end when lovers meet." What an extraordinary thought. Personally I have not experienced anything remotely close to that but I’m more than willing to believe Shakespeare had. I suppose I think about love more than anyone really should. I am constantly amazed by it's sheer power and by all its subtleties and complexities. Miles' Girlfriend passes behind the computer screen and Miles, taken with her, seems to now compose to her beauty She, however, is in a rush and doesn’t seem to notice. Mi reaches for her with one arm, kisses her hand, still play the keyboard with the other. She looks at him impatiently Oblivious to this, Miles watches her exit as he continues play.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It was Shakespeare who also said, "Love is blind". Now, that, is something I know to be true.  INT. PORSCHE - MOVING — SUNSET BOULEVARD - NIGHT - MUSIC

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUES
dialogues.text: A COUPLE drives home from a party without speaking. The Woman, in her early thirties, in the passenger seat, turn and stares steadily at her Man. Feeling her eyes on him, glances over but she seems to see right through him. He can't take it. His eyes return to the road. she nods to herself.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And for some, quite inexplicably... love fades. INT. BEDROOM - BRENTWOOD — NIGHT - MUSIC CONTINUES ARTHUR ABBOTT, eighty-some years old, gets in his Queen s bed, alone. A photo of his Beloved Wife, taken in the Fifties, sits on his night stand. Arthur takes his moment look at the photo, as he always does, before turning out light.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: For others, love is simply lost. The Wind blows a window closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GREAT LOOKING MAN, around 40, makes his way though a crowded pub. There isn't a girl in the place who doesn't look in his direction. He shyly smiles at one lucky Girl. IRIS (¥.0) -- But then of course, love can also be found. Even if just for the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Holiday party is in progress. CAMERA WENDS its way thro the festive atmosphere.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And then there's another kind of love. The cruelest kind. The one that almost kills its victims. It's called, unrequited love. of that, I am an expert. Most love stories are pretty much about people who fall in love -- with each other. But what about the rest of us? What about our stories? Those of us who fall in love alone. We are the (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: victims of the one sided affair. We are the cursed of the loved ones. We are the unloved ones. The walking wounded, the handicapped without the advantage of a great parking space. Yes, you are looking at one such individual. Yes, there...in the blue sweater. That's right. That's me. And I have willingly loved that man -- (and we see HIM across the room, drink in hand, talking to a small group) -- for over three miserable years. The absolute worst years of my life. The worst Christmases, the worst birthdays, New Year's Eves brought in by tears and Xanax. These years that I have been in love have been the darkest days of my life...all because I've been cursed by being in love with a man who does not and will not love me back. Oh, God, here he comes...heart pounding ...throat thickening..-absolutely can't swallow... all the usual symptoms. We are looking at IRIS, smartest girl in the room althoug she doesn't know it. Sweet to her core. The unrealized he of her own life. Iris slips back, deeper into the crowd and finds a friend face, HANNAH. Hannah is smoking and drinking champagne. Irie takes Hannah's glass and downs it.

dialogues.speaker: HANNA
dialogues.text: Uh-oh... Irie peeks around and spots HIM as another group has grab him. His name is JASPER. He's not conventionally good looking but has a confident and sly sexuality which draws women to him. He's clearly the biggest star in the room, paper's most important and recognized writer. Everyone wants his attention but few can actually get it.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (noticing) Oh, Jasper...You're not still?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: No, no. No. That's over. Very over. {to young passing Assistant) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter, bring Hannah another champagne and one for me, will you? Please? Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: I thought so. (on the QT) What was the story with you two? You were shagging him, weren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: IRLS
dialogues.text: More importantly, I was in love with him...truth be known.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I remember, then you found cut he was shagging that drip from circulation.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Yes. I did... which is when I stopped shagging him. I don't think we should be talking about this at the...

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: (passing by) -- Iris.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Jeffrey.

dialogues.speaker: GUY
dialogues.text: My wife loved your column last week. Read it to me out loud. Very clever. Made her cry.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Thank her for me.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: But I always see you two together. He cheated on you and you stayed friends?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Yes, well, he doesn't see it as cheating. See, I thought we were together, he said we were only “dating”.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: Does dating mean you're supposed to assume he was shagging other women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think so. Obviously. I was head over heels...you know... (embarrassed) --everyone knew. Does it look like I'm erying right now?

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: No, it looks like it's from my cigarette. Did he ever tell you he loved you?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Yes. Three, almost four times. When I reminded him of that he said it must've been as an answer to a question...which it most certainly was not.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: You know, Iris, when you catch a guy shagging another woman, you're not supposed to stay friends with him. You're supposed to never talk to the prick again, you're supposed to throw things at him, scream, call him names...nct do his fucking laundry.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I do not do his laundry. Did someone tell you I do his laundry? All we do now is...we...we do e— mails. Not when he's with "her" of course. Also when he's not with her, we talk on the phone. Sometimes for hours... {loves the thought) And then there's the occasional long lunch... (then) It's bloody torture. But he says we'd be crazy to give up our friendship, thet I'm one of the most important people in his life.

dialogues.speaker: HANNAH
dialogues.text: I never realized how pathetic you are.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Really? God, I'm so aware of it. Their champagne arrives. Iris drinks hers down quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking men. They always get us right where they want us. Who wouldn't want a fantastic girl like you in love with him...hanging on his every word...he knows anytime he wants to crawl back,..

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (confidentially) -- Actually he has said some small comments like that recently. Hasn't come right out and said it exactly but...

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR NOT IN THE PARTY MODE
dialogues.text: (passing by) Iris, did you file your story?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: No, I did not, thank you very much. {checks her watch) Down to the wire...Sorry. Iris takes off, then rushes back to Hannah.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Try to keep this between us. Iris rushes into: A TINY CUBICLE OF AN OFFICE. The walls are covered with Black and White PHOTOS of BRID AND GROOMS on their WEDDING DAY. Iris writes the UNIONS column, the only good news in the newspaper, which featur Couples on their Wedding Day in every Sunday's Style Sect She sits at her computer and brings up a story which just needs a few last words. She looks at a PHOTO of a BEAMING BRIDE AND GROOM in their Fifties,.refers to her notes.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (as she types) The groom's best friend spoke for Many guests when he said, “Hilary + will open Edward's eyes and round out his life".

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: What's it like to be the only person committed to their work while the rest of us are slumming?  Iris looks up. It's Jasper, standing in her doorway. A small bit of holly in his lapel, a drink in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: (loving him, has to look away) You Mean what's it like to be the only person not to finish their work on time. Hold on.... (types a last line)

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Look how fast that big brain of yours works. Probably a brilliant finish.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I assure you it's not. She hits a button and sends her story to her editor.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: (knowing just how to lean in the doorway) Hi...

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (dying, she adores him so much) Hi. Your column today was fantastic. Loved that line... (quoting him) "The onrushing stripping of dignity and thought from British lives." Gave me the chills. The smile on his face tells us how much he loves hearing from her.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Got you something for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Got you something too. She opens her drawer and takes out a gift.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Oh, damn, I don't actually have mine here...as a matter of fact, I may have misplaced it but I know I bought you something. Hope I didn’t lose it. Could be in my Caress

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: You want to know what it is?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: No, I can wait. But here, open yours. Jasper opens Iris' gift and finds a book.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: (cvecognizing it) You stinker... She melts. He opens the book. Seems to genuinely love it.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First edition. Where'd you find it? (seems to be really taken with her) You're so great... At this moment her world is near perfection. His eyes see to brim with tears as he looks at her...but maybe she's j imagining it. Through the glass wall of her office, they their EDITOR IN CHIEF, HUGH BUCKLEY standing on a chair t quiet down the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hate that we can never talk.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I know... They exit together into:

dialogues.speaker: THE NEWSROOM
dialogues.text: The crowd has gathered. Iris turns and has somehow lost Jasper. She looks for him as she stands alone, in the bac near her office.

dialogues.speaker: HUGE
dialogues.text: First of all, to each and every one of you, a very Merry Christmas. We are not officially closed, as you well know but with any luck, we will not go to war, the flu will not spread and the Queen will not abdicate. Given that, we may be able to get by with a smaller than (MORE) .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: normal staff. Now, before some of you rush off on holiday I have one rather important announcement. This effects Iris. Iris, where are you? Ixis, surprised, raises her hand and is pushed forward.

dialogues.speaker: HUGH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Iris, T have a tip for you.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Excellent.

dialogues.speaker: HUGE
dialogues.text: A wedding was privately announced earlier today which I don't believe any other paper in town knows about and I want you to be the first to report on this particular “union” as it is between two of our most esteemed colleagues. May I introduce, the newly engaged -- Sarah Smith-Alcott and Jasper Bloom. SARAH steps forward. A sincere, make no waves kind of gir A second banana if ever there was one. She lights up as s turns to Jasper who joins her, taking her hand. CAMERA SLOWLY PUSHES IN on Iris, trying desperately not t ery in front of everyone she knows. Jasper says a few wor but Tris doesn't hear them. When he finishes, he catches Iris in the crowd. She gives him a small approving nod an the bravest possible smile. As their eyes connect, someon pats Jasper on the back and his attention is once again g and Iris is once again, left alone.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: as she escapes through the crowd and INTO HER OFFICE. She takes her coat off the back of her door, slips into it th sees the wrinkled wrapping paper from her gift. She picks ub, crumples it, then notices the book is sitting on an e table, forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (holding back her tears) Yeah, that's right...I'm sooo great. Greatest idiot that ever lived.  10.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: tris, holding the book on her lap, sits in an empty train car, a tissue in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow falls as Iris walks the curve of the cobblestoned st of her small village. At one end of the street is a churc At the other, is the village pub which is overflowing wit patrons. As Iris passes the pub, someone calls her name b she doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A picture postcard stone cottage sits nestled in a winter garden. This is one of the smallest houses you've ever se Tris walks the narrow footbridge up to her front gate. Sh opens the gete and a bell rings. A dog can be heard barki inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iris ENTERS, turns on the light and is greeted by her dog CHARLIE.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Hey, look who it is...Give me a kiss...give mé a.... (she hugs him) You're so warm. Okay. Okay. Give me a sec, Charlie, I gotta take off my boots. Hold on... iris falls into a soft upholstered chair. She pulls off h boots, sits there for a second in her wet coat, wet hair, looks at her dog.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Guess what? And then she bursts inte tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Man we saw driving the Porsche (on page 2), wakes up couch. Pillow under his head, blanket over him. He is in great looking room in a great. looking, sun filled house. 6,000 square feet in prime Brentwood. The house has the relaxed good taste you get with a smart decorator. The Man is ETHAN, artistic good locks, almost forty, tous hair, T-shirt, boxers, vintage Rolex and a large dose of narcissism which he has never discussed with his shrink.  ii. Ethan sits up, runs his hand through his hair, looks arou and catches the eye of the uniformed Gardener, blowing Eucalyptus leaves outside a wall of windows.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN WALKS THROUGH THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: calling, "Amanda". He checks out the oversized Kitchen, t Media Room, the Gym, the expansive Home Office. He passes Christmas Tree with a Jewish star on top, CLIMBS THE CENT HALL STAIRS.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Amanda? ives Ethan a nod toward the bedroom and a look that sugge A HOUSEKEEPER passes him ON HER WAY DOWN the stairs. She giv he* s in trouble. Ethan continues up the stairs and stops outside of the MA BEDROOM DOOR. He hesitates, opens it and A SNEAKER FLIES HIS HEAD. HE DUCKS. The thrower of the sneaker is AMANDA WOODS, wearing white pajamas, a bed-head of fabulous hair, a necklace with som sort of diamond pendant and a red Kabbalah string bracele Amanda wouldn't know how to play the victim if she was on Men don't just fall for this woman, they fall under her spell. Fiercely intelligent, blazing eyes, a big city gir with a small town in her past. At the moment, she's about explode.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: May I just say again that I didn't sleep with her.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (pacing) Okay. Right. Your receptionist needs to work ‘til 3 in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: A bunch of us were working all night...she wanted to hang out.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Okay, then swear on my life that you didn't sleep with her. {she gets very still and waits) Go ahead.  12. Ethan starts to open his mouth, then stops. Another SNEAK FLIES at him. He ducks it.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your receptionist, Ethan??? That fake-boobed, lip-linered, G-string sticking out... She can't even pronounce people's names! Amanda starts to quickly gather some of Ethan's books and things.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See. This is why I knew we shouldn't get married. This is why I told you never to give up your house. I knew it. Inside, somehow I knew this.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: First of all, i did not sleep with her and secondly, we've had problems for over a year. You don't want. to deal with that, I know, but we have... so let’s not make this about Amy.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm well aware we've had problems for over a year. If I work a little too much I never stop hearing about it but if you work too much, Maestro, it's for the sake of your "music".

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: If you work too much?! Amanda, you cut 75 trailers this year. You put a cutting room in the house, you sleep with your blackberry. Look at your side of the bed...it's like a work station..... When was the last time we had sex? Want to take a guess?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, no one has time for sex.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: That's not true. Okay?  13.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Okay, that's it! You absolutely slept with her! It's official. We're finished! You gotta get your clothes and all your crap and... {shooing him out) Can you get out? Seriously, you have to get out.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I thought you wanted me to get my clothes? She backs him OUT THE DOOR and DOWN THE STAIRS:

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: ¥ou know what I really think Ethan? I don't think you ever really loved me. How's that? I think you loved the idea of you and me...but not so Much me...not Me. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I don't even know what that means except that you're criticizing the way I loved you. I did the best I could. Is anyone good enough for that job? That hurts. She opens the FRONT DOOR, tosses Ethan his ke then moves him OUT THE DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I'1l send you your things. Ethan now stands OUTSIDE THE DOOR in his boxer shorts. Amanda faces him standing INSIDE THE HOUSE. The Gardeners try not to listen.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You know you do this, right? You screw up every relationship you've ever been in. It's what you do. Amanda SLAMS THE DOOR on him. As she RUNS BACK UP THE STA she HEARS:

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Something about you doesn't really want to be a couple. Not really. You resist it...in your own way.  14

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN OUT FRONT OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: YELLING up to her Bedroom Window.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: And it's hard to detect how you even do it ‘cause nobody's quite as smart as you, so you're hard to catch at it, but it always surfaces and this is what happens. Amanda OPENS an Upstairs Window, looks down.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: What happens?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (looking up at her) Things end. Just like you kmew they would. Look, you know how I feel about you. There's nobody like you, but you don't want to be what I need. {corrects himself) Not, "I" need... you know what I mean...

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I would never cheat on you. Not under any conditions.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: And neither would I. Okay?! Look at me...I'm sweating like a God damned pig and look at you, you‘re the only woman on earth who breaks up with her boyfriend and doesn't shed a tear. That means something doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: So I'm cursed because I don't need you enough and... why does it bug ’ you so much that I can't cry?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I didn't say you don't need me enough although that's probably true too. Amanda rubs her chest. Ouch.  15.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Abhhh...Esophogial spasm. Big one... Ow! (sees him looking ashen) I'll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I know. I was thinking about me.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (through her pain) Ethan, it's over so we might as well be honest with each other. (very vulnerable) dust. tell me. Did you sleep with her? (He still doesn't answer) Just say it. What's the difference at this point? Why torture me? Put me out of my misery. (rubs her chest} What are we doing, here? Just tell me. bo what's right for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (beaten) Okay. (that got her attention) Yes. Okay. I slept with her. You happy? I've been sleeping with her. She's in love with me. She's young and... The Gardener looks over at Ethan, shaking his head. What

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I-I'm not proud of this... Amanda nods, disappears into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Amanda..? A beat and the FRONT DCOR OPENS and Amanda very calmly CROSSES TO ETHAN.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Did you say, "Am I happy?"  16

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I didn't mean that. You get me nuts then I say things I don't mean.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You know what cheating is Ethan?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: {doesn't want to hear it) Just.. What? No, what?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It's a coward's way of breaking up. And at it's core, what it is...is unkind. Because it makes everyone involved, including me, feel cheap and crazy. It's a bad way to end things because this is how I'll always think of you. Not as that guy I spent three years with and went to Hawaii with and took cooking lessons with... You will always and forever be the ass-hole that lied and cheated and nothing you ever say or do from this moment on will ever change my mind about you. In the world of love...not that I'm such a genius at it...but in the world of love...cheating is simply not acceptable.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (not dealing with her) Okay...

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: And the fact that in this fight, you made this about me and not you makes “ass-hole" the nicest thing I can ever say about you.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: No matter what you think and I know you have a very high opinion of yourself -- this isn’t all me. And’ when you're not in such a rage, you'll know it too.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Maybe when the rage subsides and I stop having visions of you two TOGETHER... I'll see your side.  Amanda turns, starts to walk away then comes right back, makes a fist and punches Ethan in the face. Twice. He los his balance and falls on his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda ENTERS out of breath, adrenaline pumping. She jump up and down out of frustration and lets out a Scream. BRISTOL, Amanda's PREGNANT ASSISTANT arrives from the kitchen, holding a spiral notebook and a pen and catches tail end of this.

dialogues.speaker: BRISTOL
dialogues.text: Is this a bad time?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: No. I'm just flipping out a little. Fuck! I'm alright. Shit! I'm okay. What's up? Fortunately, Amanda is often seved by her unique ability change subjects with lightning speed.

dialogues.speaker: BRISTOL
dialogues.text: Ben needs you.

dialogues.speaker: INT, AMANDA'S GUEST HOUSE
dialogues.text: which has been turned into a CUTTING ROOM. Movie one shee are stacked against the wall. Another wall is filled with videotapes. Sitting at an AVID is BEN, trim, faded John K T-shirt, two day growth of beard. Amanda enters. We can s a beautiful pool and patic umbrellas behind her.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Is it better?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, your changes were good. TI just need you to sign off on it so I can get it over to the studio. They want it on the air tomorrow. Amanda nods. Ben hits a button on the Avid and a TV spot a movie plays. We hear THAT FAMILIAR NARRATOR..... “This Christmas, Columbia Pictures Presents..." The movie is a Black Buddy Comedy/Action Film. The images are familiar: Helicopters, Male Stars in Prada suits, Uzis pointed at t lens, Blondes in bikinis, cars careening out of control.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (when it's over) It finally looks like a hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why they pay you the big bucks.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: But I still think you cut a little too fast off the guy in the Doo Rag. And try putting the Blonde before the house blowing up, and hang on Will a few frames longer when he says, "Don't hate me ‘cause I‘m pretty.” His smile's great. (heading out) And make "Christmas Day" twice as big. And try it in red. Buta happy red.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (taking notes) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Okay! We're done! (impulsively) Hey. Why don't we take off for a few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I'm not kidding. Everyone elee in town takes off for Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: BRISTOL
dialogues.text: But you always say this is our busiest... AMANDA. -- I know, but we’ve got 20 people in the office. They can handie things for a few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: You'll jet them handle things?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: {rubs her chest) I think I gotta get out of town. I need some peace and quiet...or whatever it is people go away for. You know what I really want to do? I want to eat carbs without wanting (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: to kill myself. I want to read a book. Not a magazine article...an actual book. I read these reviews, T buy the books but I never read them. Ouch! (rubs her chest) Did you read that article in The New York Times last Sunday? Severe stress makes women age prematurely, because the stress causes the DNA in our cells to shrink until they can no longer replicate. So when we're stressed we look haggard. Just women...not men. Remember when they used to say single women over 35 were more likely to be killed by a terrorist than get married? That was... horrible. So now our generation is also not getting married and bonus....real terrorists actually became part of our lives s0 now the stress of it all shows up in our faces, making us look haggard while Ethan goes on looking cute forever and fucking his 24 year old receptionist.

dialogues.speaker: BRISTOL
dialogues.text: I think a vacation sounds like a solid idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda sits at her computer, googling vacation spots.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (typing) Okay...where do I want to go? By myself...at Christmas... By myself, "depressed" at Christmas. All alone on vacation. Alone, alone...totally alone. She stops typing. Tries to cry. Quivers her bottom lip, quick breaths...she can't make tears. Stops trying.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {reading what has shown up on her screen) Worry free vacations. Good. Where's that? (reads) Bora Bora... (tries out the thought) “Kayak for one".... Noooo. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reads on} Caribbean? (thinks about it) Ican't. All couples and kids... which I do not have. {continues googling) Vacation rentals... (likes this idea) Yeah. Hole up in a house somewhere, disappear for a few weeks,...nobody'1l know me. Good. (reads) Where do you want to go on your next vacation? Three clicks is all it takes to Search, Select and Contact your perfect vacation home exchange partner. Click here and pick a country. She CLICKS and a FULL PAGE OF COUNTRY NAMES show up. Everything from Albania to Zanzibar.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {reads) Where do they speak English? She moves the mouse to ENGLAND and CLICKS. A FULL PAGE OF NAMES OF TOWNS AND CITIES in England shows up.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reads) Click on a city. She randomly picks Cotswold. CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: BMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reads) Barn converted to modern house in beautiful Cotswold... I like the sound of that..."Cotswold*. A PHOTO of the HOUSE in Cotswold shows up. It couldn't lo more ordinary.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- Which looks exactly like the Valley. (CLICKS on ANOTHER TOWN) Isolated country house with distant views. I could do isolated. A PHOTO of the HOUSE appears. Big, gothic, on a hill.  2i.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: oy, The Shining... (she quickly CLICKS oN ANOTHER TOWN, reads) Christmas in the country. A fairy tale English cottage set in a tranquil country garden. Snuggle up by the old brick fireplace and enjoy a glowing fire and a cup of COCOa..+ {just the description is soothing) An enchanting oasis of tranquility in a guiet English hamlet just forty minutes from exciting London. Amanda CLICKS and a PHOTO of IRIS' COTTAGE SHOWS UP. She smiles as we HEAR the sound of a TEA KETTLE GOING OFF:

dialogues.speaker: INT, IRIS' COTTAGE
dialogues.text: It's eight hours later in England and Iris is making a cu tea before bed. She looks wiped out. It's been a hard night. A light snow falls outside the windows. She hears her COMPUTER PING. She sits at the kitchen table and look at her laptop. It's a HOME EXCHANGE INSTANT MESSAGE. It says:

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Renting my house? IRIS types back: Sorry, it's only available for home exchange.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (to herself) Home exchange??

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: We switch houses, cars, everything. I haven't done it before but friends of mine have. Supposed to be great. Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: {staring at her computer) Please say America.  22. AMANDA types: Z.A.

dialogues.speaker: ERIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jackpot! Wiping her tears, IRIS types: I've never been there but always wanted to go. I'm Iris, by the way. I'm very norma Neat freak. Healthy. Non smoker. Single.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to herself) -- Hate my horrible life. AMANDA types: I'm Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (to herself) Loser, loner, complicated wreck. IRIS types: Hu. AMANDA answers: Hi. AMANDA thinks abeut this, then writes: Must say, your hou looks idyilic. Just what I need. IRIS types: Thank you. What does your place look like? I don't need much...just love the idea of being 6090 miles here. AMANDA answers quickly: I totally get that. My place is nice -- little bigger than yours. IRIS: Not hard to be. AMANDA laughs, types: I have Three Bedrooms, Four Baths, Kitchen, Family Room, Media Room...

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (reading all this) Is she kidding? AMANDA keeps going: Home office, Gym, Pool and Guest Hous Assuming this will never work, IRIS types: JI have a kitc bedroom, bathroom, living room. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {to herself) Nice knowing you. AMANDA writes: Sounds perfect. Both Women sit and look at their computers.  23. IRIS types: And I have a dog. AMANDA answers: That's cool. Iris smiles. AMANDA: Can I ask you one thing? IRIS: Sure. AMANDA: Are there any men in your town? IRIS: Honestly? AMANDA: Yes. IRTS: Zero. AMANDA: When can I come? TRIS hesitates, then types: Tomorrow too soon??? AMANDA, going on impulse: Tomorrow's perfect actually. IRIS quickly types: Okay, forms to fill cut, etc., but we on for two weeks, starting tomorrow. Both Women SIT AND STARE at their computers. A little nervous. AMANDA: Can I call you to talk in person? IRIS relaxes: Love if you would. And as quickly as Iris types in her phone number and SEND the PHONE RINGS. Iris picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hellot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane is boarding and through the Crowd of Passengers see Iris making her way through the Coach Section to her seat. Naturally, it's in the middle of three seats and th seats on either side of her are empty. She settles into t center seat, looks up and sees a great looking Italian Gu looking at the seat right next to her. She can't believe luck. He smiles at her. She smiles back. He’s then joined by his Beautiful Skinny Girlfriend who points him to the row. Then, two very pleasing looking Women in their Fifties st at Iris' row and squeeze into the empty seats knocking he  24. around a bit. Iris' Blackberry BEEPS. She checks it. It’s from JASPER. It says:

dialogues.speaker: JASPER.
dialogues.text: Iris closes her eyes, trying to will willpower. Her eyes to the line: How do I reach you? Her eyes well up as she writes back: Dear Jasper, (she deletes the “Dear") Jasper, We both kno I need to fall out of love with you. Would be great if yo would let me try. xx. (Deletes the xx). Iris. The Woman next to Iris has been reading over her shoulder pats Iris‘ arm.

dialogues.speaker: A STACK OF BOOKS
dialogues.text: The size you would take with you if you were going away f year. The stack sits next to Amanda who wears the British Air Eye Shades, sweats, noisy bangle bracelets. Harper's Bazaar lies open on her lap. With her eyes covered, she takes a Pepsid AC, throws it d with some water, rubs her chest and closes the window sha She pulls up the comforter, adjusts her pillow. A beat an she lifts her eye shades to her forehead, stares straight at the plane's ceiling and we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE -
dialogues.text: Amanda Woods is proud to present -- "Her Life". She had it all. The job, the house, the guy. This holiday season find out what Amanda doesn't have. As if to shut the Guy out, Amanda snaps her eye shades ba over her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: A BRITISH PASSPORT
dialogues.text: is STAMPED by a U.S. Customs officer. He hands it back to excited IRIS.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Wish me luck! The Customs Guy says nothing. Iris moves on. A beat and s returns.  25.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm a little superstitious. Could you wish me luck?

dialogues.speaker: CUSTOMS OFFICER
dialogues.text: Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER STAMP
dialogues.text: hits AMANDA'S PASSPORT. A British Customs Officer passes passport back to Amanda. She yawns, wearing sunglasses. HELICOPTER SHOT - FREEWAYS INTERSECTING — DAY A SAN DIEGO FREEWAY SIGN —- “SUNSET BOULEVARD" ~ DAY IRIS, in the backseat of a TAXI, looks out the open windo like a kid, her hair blowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mercedes drives through the picturesque village which i now covered in snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DRIVER slows to a stop and turns to the backseat.. AM is asleep wearing the British Air eye shades.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Miss? Miss? Amanda jumps, lifting her eyes shades.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're here. Amanda lowers the window letting in the cold air. She loo out at a snow covered stone wall.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (disoriented) This can't be it.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (pointing the other way) It's just down that lane, but I'll never be able to turn at the other end. Think you can make it from here? Amanda squints trying to see how long the lane is.  26.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mercedes pulls away and leaves Amanda in heels, jeans shearling coat, a long red scarf, a Balenciaga bag, a car on, and a huge black Tumi suitcase. She tosses her scarf over her shoulder, pops the handle on her suitcase and be dragging it behind her, down the snow covered lane. Whoop She skids, almost falls, regains her balance. A clump of falls from a tree branch, hitting her smack on the head.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Thank you. CLOSE — AMANDA'S SNOW COVERED MANOLOS coming to a stop. Tilt up to Amanda, out of breath, arriv at Iris' little gate. She wipes snow from the stone wall reveals the house number. She looks ahead and sees the TI COTTAGE, nestled under snow covered branches.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (to the house) I'm here... Amanda opens the gate, the bell on it rings a frozen litt ring and she drags her things up to the front door, lifts flower pot and finds a key. She inserts the key and is greeted by Iris‘ dog, Charlie. She pets him as she turns on the lights, looks around the cottage, sees it's small, charming Bedroom with pitched ceilings, tiny Bathroom, cramped Kitchen, cozy little Liv Room. Amanda stands between her bags, able to see the ful place as she does a 360.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What am I doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Taxi pulls away revealing Iris OUT FRONT OF AMANDA'S GATE, holding her one smallish suitcase. She's overdresse for a warm winter day in L.A. She stands beneath an orang tree, the sun shining brightly on her as she looks throug the gate at Amanda's spread.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Holy shit. She presses a button on the CALL BOX.  27.

dialogues.speaker: BRISTOL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Iris?

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: (getting too close to the box) Yes. I'm here. Hello.

dialogues.speaker: BRISTOL'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hey... Come on in. Iris tries pushing on the gate when suddenly it automatic swings open.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (leans back to the box) Sorry. A wind greets her as she carries her suitcase up the grav driveway. Pregnant Bristol EXITS THE FRONT DOOR holding a binder.

dialogues.speaker: BRISTOL
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Bristol, I'm Amanda's assistant. I'm really sorry to do this but your plane was late and I have a doctor's appointment, so I've got to take off.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Oh, no problem.

dialogues.speaker: BRISTOL
dialogues.text: Thanks. I made you this binder, it explains how everything in the house works. The alarm, the password, the gate code...I gave you all the speed diai numbers for police, fire, gardeners, pool man, housekeeper, me. Directions for the phones, the sound system, the TVs, DVD players and TiVos. The equipment in the gym is pretty self explanatory. The exterior lights go on automatically and sco do the sprinklers so you don't have to worry about that. Here’s clickers for the gate and the garage and keys to the front door, the side door, the mail box and the Prius. {sees Iris’ expression) Don’t worry. It's only a house. It's easier than it looks.  28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iris ENTERS, takes it all in...the beautiful decor, the l generous rooms. Her mind is blown. She places her things by the door and immediately checks the house. We follow her as she DARTS IN and OUT of rooms SCREAMING FOR JOY. She runs UP THE STAIRS, ENTERS THE LUXURIOUSLY LARGE BEDROOM, checks out the OVERSIZED BATHR and SHRIEKS. She opens a door into a DREAM CLOSET. It's insanely BIG. She sees her small English self in the larg closet mirror.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (to her mirror image) This is the most brilliant thing that ever happened to you. INT. IRIS' COTTAGE —- ENGLAND - THE SAME TIME Amanda is finishing unpacking, trying to squeeze one more thing into Iris' teeny tiny little closet. She gets it in and slams the door closed. Now... what to do with her emp suitcase. She rolls it under the bed.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Okay. Now what?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA EXITS THE BACK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: pulling her coat around her to keep warm. It's getting da She spots a garden bench, dusts off the snow. Sits on it. The quiet is astounding.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I have not screwed up every relationship I've been in! She tries to CRY again. Really gives it her all. Nothing comes. She tries again...waits. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER GUY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Amanda was lost but she knew, in the game of life... She bolts off of the bench and out of FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROAD
dialogues.text: Things are flying by fast and the trees on the side of th road are way too close. A PUNK BAND blares from the Radio  29.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: is driving Iris' electric Blue Mini and has obviously nev driven on the left side of the road before. She pulls int

dialogues.speaker: THE TOWN
dialogues.text: Whoa...hard to make the turn from the left. A few shopper browse past local shops and watch as the Mini fish tails the street. Small children run to their parents. Amanda parks, gets out of the car, grabs her chest to catch her breath.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (to kids) Sorry. (then) Okay, that was hell. She looks around...sees the Pub, the Post Office, the Boo Shop, the Butcher and the Market. As she heads toward the market, she looks left and a car from the right almost hi her. HONKKKK!!! She leaps out of its way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: small, very English. Bad Christmas music plays in the b.g Amanda pushes a small cart and drinks from a bottle of wi She loads up her cart with fresh baguettes, pastries, smo salmon, local cheeses, Christmas puddings.

dialogues.speaker: CHECK OUT STAND
dialogues.text: As a chubby Female Clerk rings up Amanda's goodies.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Someone's having a party tonight.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Ch, yeah. Amanda takes a swig out of the wine bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda sits on Iris' bed, in pajamas and a big sweater an her scarf, eating Christmas pudding and watching The Offi on a15" TV. She pops a Pepsid AC in her mouth and washes down with wine. The Office cuts to commercial and Amanda' spot comes on. "This Christmas, Columbia Pictures is prou present..." Amanda watches, mouthing the words. Then at t end -- twice as big and in red letters -- Christmas Day.  30.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: And that's why I make the big bucks.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Amanda makes a fire in the LIVING ROOM FIREPLACE. It's no so @asy without the little gas knob. A LITTLE LATER, she puts on a Supremes CD and sings along. "You can't hurry love, no, you just got to wait." LATER, holding a glass o wine, she looks at Iris' books, reading their titles...there's so many of them. LATER STILL, with an op book on her lap, Amanda sits on the couch, looking at Charlie, the dog. They seem to be having a staring contes CUT To:

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA'S SUITCASE
dialogues.text: being tossed on the bed. Amanda throws in her clothes.

dialogues.speaker: A HOCKNEY POOL SPLASH
dialogues.text: Iris swims laps in AMANDA'S POOL as the sun sets on a bal breezy winter day in Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ixis, barefoot, in jeans, blouse, damp hair, scans Amanda WALL OF DVDs....there’s so many of them. Then, she looks a BASKET FULL OF CLICKERS...there's so many of them. She gets intimidated and reaches for the binder Bristol gave The Phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? (notices "GATE" is LIT UP on phone) Gate? Oh, no. Disaster. Iris looks at the multi-lined phone, then thumbs frantica though the binder.

dialogues.speaker: AN AUDI CONVERTIBLE
dialogues.text: Miles (from page 1) is behind the wheel. His Girlfriend, Maggie sits next to him, talking on her cell. Miles is listening to a movie score on CD.  31.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: (into phone) No, Miles is dropping me at yoga. Shut Uppp. Who was he with? Maggie turns down the Volume on the CD.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Maggie! This is the best part. Maggie holds up her finger as in “one sec". Miles PUSHES CALL BUTTON again.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS' VOICE
dialogues.text: (from the speaker box) -- I'm sorry. Hello. I'm here. Can you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: It's Miles. Amanda?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Wo. Sorry. Amanda's not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Oh, FU!! (BUZZ)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles and Maggie both look at the Speaker Box as the gate OPENS.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS' VOICE
dialogues.text: If you heard that, I'm terribly sorry. Miles pulls into the driveway, GETS OUT of the convertibl Maggie stays in the car, still on the phone. Iris opens t door, sees Miles.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Hello... The afternoon breeze blows her hair as MOVIE MUSIC drifts of the car. It's nostalgic and romantic and colors the scene.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Hi. Sorry to bother you... The wind blows even stronger, rustling Iris' blouse.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (Looking at the trees blowing) Santa Anas.  32

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: The wind...it's what makes it so warm this time of year. Legend has it, when the Santa Anas blow, anything can happen.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Good day to arrive then.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You just got here?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: First time in L.A.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Really? Well, people bad mouth this place all the time but give it a chance. L.A. is highly misunderstood. There's a lot of magic around here. Plus, there aren't many places where the nights smell like jasmine and the days smell like orange blossoms. {the wind blows again) I'm Miles, I work for Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Amanda's ex-boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Yeah. Too bad about that, huh..? Do you know what time Amanda will be back?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Amanda's in England...on holiday. I'm staying here for a few weeks while she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Oh, that's a little funky ‘cause Ethan left some things here and asked me to pick them up. Is that still cool, or...?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: You’re his...?  33.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Well, I'm a composer, like Ethan but I help him out with whatever...

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: {referring to the music coming out of the car) Did you compose this?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: No, this is the great Ennio Morricone, it's the score from Cinema Paradiso.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Oh. I loved that movie. I forgot how beautiful the music was. They both listen appreciatively when the horn HONKS. Mile turns. Maggie is clearly ready to go.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would it be all right if you came around tomorrow and I'1l check all this out with Amanda's assistant?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Sure. No problem. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (extends her hand) I'm Iris.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Miles.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Right. The Santa Anas breeze past them again. As Miles gets back the car and pulls out the Exit Gate, Iris notices the ora trees in the yard. As the wind drifts, she smells their blossoms. Arthur, (the Older Man introduced on page 2) slowly walks the open gate on a walker. Supporting his arm is his frum iccking Black Nurse.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ‘Evening... Arthur does not look in her direction. Iris notices them heading for the house next docr then spots a SMALL PACKAG  34. sitting outside the gate. Iris quickly rushes to it, grabbing it just before the gate closes. INT. KITCHEN — MOMENTS LATER Iris opens THE PACKAGE, a vinyl cooler bag, and inside, f a small calorie conscious ZONE MEAL.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Why would anyone with this kitchen have a meal delivered? Iris opens the Kitchen Cupboards. Nothing but low carb foods, almonds, Pepcid AC, Mylanta. She opens the refrigerator. Soy milk, one egg, 50 bottles of water, two bottles of Pinot Grigio. Iris turns back and looks at the Zone Meal. WIDE SHOT - THE KITCHEN — MOMENTS LATER This gorgeous, Viking-Ranged, Sub-Zeroed, every Williams— Sonoma gadget-ever-made-kitchen has nothing in it to actu eat so Iris SITS ON A STOOL at the HUGE ISLAND and dines Amanda's tiny ZONE MEAL and a glass of wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are CLOSE ON IRIS' LAPTOP SCREEN. We HEAR: "You've got Mail!” with an English accent.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS' E-MATLS
dialogues.text: are displayed. Her eyes scan them and stop when she finds what she wants. An e-mail from: JASPER_BLOOM@TIMES.CO.UK. With her heart beating in great anticipation, she opens h up.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER'S E-MAIL
dialogues.text: Know we must talk. Maybe it is good you are on holiday. Give us each a chance to deal with current agendas. Trying hard to be clear to myself these days. Know this... I think of you and smile so deeply that it can no longer be called a smile. Maybe scientists will discover new word to describe. Sleep well. Jas Her heart races. Her legs melt. How does he dc it? Six thousand miles away and she’s still in the palm of his ha She braces herself and closes the computer.  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iris climbs into Amanda's king size bed, looks at the clo It's SIX P.M.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: (counts quickly) Seven, eight, nine ten, eleven, twelve, one... Two a.m. in London. She yawns, notices a BUTTON by the bed, pushes it and is surprised when BLACK OUT BLINDS SIMULTANEOUSLY LOWER all around the room, delivering the room into total darkness. the Screen turns BLACK, we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He doesn't love you. Forget him. Forget him.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER CLOCK
dialogues.text: tells us it’s TWO A.M. CAMERA PANS to Amanda, lying WIDE AWAKE in Iris's small double bed. She's not even a little tired. Suddenly, a LOUD KNOCKING on the FRONT DOOR. Amand quickly rises, runs into the LIVING ROOM. Charlie barks.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (cautiously) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: It's me. Open up, it's freezing.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Iris...It's Graham. Open the fucking door before I take a fucking leak in your fucking flower pot. Amanda quickly OPENS the door and we find the rakishly handsome GRAHAM (from page 2). All twinkly eyes and ruffl hair. He's some exotic and pleasing concoction of helplessness and cockiness. Just at the sight of him, Ama is for the first time in her life, speechless -- which me this man has already changed her.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (clearly drunk) You're not Iris.  36.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: No, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Oh...then, sorry for my profanity, I wasn't expecting...you.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I~I wasn't expecting you either.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Nevertheless...May I just....

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, you have to um....

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (ENTERING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do... (passing her, shakes her hand) I'm Graham. iris' brother.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Amanda Woods. I'm... staying here.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Amandawoods...Is that all one word?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (watching him disappear into the bathroom) No. No it's not. The Bathroom Door shuts. Amanda catches herself in the mirror. She tries to fix her hair a little when Graham re enters. God, he's even cuter the second time you see him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (locking around) So Iris is... Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She didn't tell you?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Not that I remember.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: She's in L.A..

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: That's not possible. Iris never leaves town.  37

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (laughs) Neither do I. She listed this cottage on a Home Exchange Website. I found it and we switched houses...for two weeks. For vacation. She's in my house in L.A. and I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: No.... People actually do that?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Apparently. Seems here I am... in my pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: She did call me a few times this morning but I didn't get a chance to get back to her. Feel awful now. (a bit woozy) Do you mind if I sit, I feel I'm going to bump in to you.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: ~- No, no. Sure...sit... (Graham sits on the sofa) You okay?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, fine. Really sorry about the intrusion. Obviously, I had no idea about this exchange thing and although I may not appear it, I am actually Iris' very respectable big brother, however, on the rare, or not so rare occasion that I come into town and get inordinately pissed, my sweet sister, puts me up so I don't get behind the wheel. Pathetic explanation but, unfortunately it's become a bit of a routine... (to dog) Hello Charles. Charlie nuzzles Graham’s leg.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So how's it going so far...this exchange thing... I mean, up until I showed up and ruined your night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually it's not going so great. I'm leaving tomorrow. On a noon plane.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Oh. When did you get here?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Uh, three o'clock. Today.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Abhh. We made a great impression on you, have we?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It's not that....no, it's just that I'm not quite myself right now and I came here on a stupid whim. Honestly, I never thought about anything less, very unlike me...and the thing is, I don't know what I'm doing here... so E thought I should go home...where I at least know how to drive a car. Would you like something to drink? Glass of water? Tea? Wine maybe?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Wine would be good. Will you have a glass?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: -- Uh...sure. 38. Amanda crosses to the Kitchen, brings over an open bottle two glasses.

dialogues.speaker: GRAAEM
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'm really sorry but 1 forgot your name?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes. Amanda Woods. Very good name. It looks like you. He makes a fist, indicating she appears strong. to him. She sits next  She's not

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You think I'm... (she imitates his fist) Really?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Well, I imagine everybody does, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yes, but they don't usually spot it this fast. Anyway, I don't feel BSOe seve (makes the fist) Whatever. Like it matters.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Are you married?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Married? No, no... No. I'm not. No.... No.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: That makes two of us. quite sure where this is headed.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, is it horrible if I stay? Z'li be gone before you even wake up. I promise you will never lay eyes on me again.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: No, sure, it's fine. Let me just get you a blanket.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: It's in the cupboard there...on top of the scrabble. Amanda takes out the blanket and an extra pillow and hand them to Graham.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So why is it that you aren't guite yourself? I'm sort of curious.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: oh, why..? {sitting again) Because I...I just broke up with someone...yesterday and I guess (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: what I was feeling was that I didn't want to be alone over the holidays and I thought if I was somewhere else, maybe I wouldn't realize I was alone but then I got here and I've never felt more alone in my life. Big surprise. (embarrassed) Bet you're glad you knocked on this door?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: T am actually.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Well. Sorry and good night. Graham leans over and kisses her. Almost routinely.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Sweet dreams. She digests this, then:

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Do you think you could... Would you mind... trying that again? He kisses her again.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Bad?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Weird. I mean, kissing a total stranger.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Really? I do it all the time. She leans in, kisses him. Something's not working.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Maybe if I shut my eyes. She shuts her syes and Graham kisses her closed eye lids then kisses her on the mouth. Amanda's eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, um...given that I'm in a bit of a personal crisis and find myself in a total stranger's home in a town I can't actually remember the name of and considering you showed up and you're insanely good (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: looking and really drunk and probably won’t remember me anyway, I'm thinking.... we should have sex. If you want. He looks at her hard.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: That's a fantastic proposition.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah...but I’m serious.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: So am I.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: And not that it matters, but I've never said anything like that in my life. I've had nearly a bottle of wine myself and it's just ... the whole knowing I'll never see you again thing is sort of exciting. This is what a vacation is supposed to be, right? You're supposed to vacate your life. Do the unexpected.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You know this all sounded really wonderful until I became the cabana boy.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: And you're funny. Which is a real bonus.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes, well, never meet me when I'm sober.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Deal. He pauses, thinks about that, then kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Also I should warn you...I'm not very good at this.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: "This" being?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Um. Sex.  42.

dialogues.speaker: GRAEAM
dialogues.text: Oh that can't be true.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I know. I look like I'm hot but...I'm apparently net. It's what I've been told.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: That's harsh.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I agree. Wevertheless, the guy I was living with, mentioned it once or twice. A girl doesn't forget a comment like that. Not even me. But I mean, how bad could I be...sex is pretty basic. Am I pretty much talking you out of it?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Strangely, not at all. How do you feel about foreplay?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I think it's overrated. Significantly...overrated.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You are quickly becoming one of the most interesting girls I've ever met. Amanda rises, grabs the wine bottle and walks to the ster turns it on, then walks backwards, facing Graham, leading into the bedroom. Graham follows her, unbuttoning his shi as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at you, you're already better than you think.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, COTTAGE
dialogues.text: Smoke drifts from the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda, now in a robe, is trying to figure out the coffee maker when Graham tentatively ENTERS FROM THE BEDROOM, fu dressed.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Sood merning.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (shyly) Good morning. She continues futzing with the coffee maker.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Can I help you with that?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I should know how to do this... Graham plugs it in.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ah, you have te plug them in over here... Graham laughs. They're quite close tc each other which ma them both a little uncomfortable. Graham opens a cupbcard takes out a bottle of Tylenol. Takes two.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Care for one?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I already had four.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: So...Amanda...I just want to...

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, listen... You don't have to worry about a thing here. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (unsettled) Okay...

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I mean it was great meeting you and everything.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (seriously) Definitely. (then) And, just for the record, your ex- boyfriend is, in my opinion, quite mistaken about you.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you were drunk.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Not that drunk. Graham's cell phone RINGS. It's on the table, near Amanda She picks it up. Sees it says, SCPHIE is calling.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (hands it to him) Sophie...

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (embarrassed, turns it off) I'll call her back... Amanda nods, opens the cupboards looking for the coffee c Graham opens the correct cupboard, hands one to her.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You don't want one?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I should really be going.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: -- Listen, I know you don't want to get involved...and you're leaving today and just so you know, I have rather enormous issues of my own and even if you were staying, I can promise you, you wouldn't for one minute like...

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (stopping him) -~ You don't have to do this. I'm damaged in this area myself. And anyway, I mean..-honesty, we hardly know each other.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Well, I wouldn't exactly say that. Anyway, I just wanted to assure you, you're better off.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: No need to go on. Right. Well, I just wanted to be sure you are ckay (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: because I'm somewhat emotionally dysfunctional at this point in my life and it seems I tend to hurt women simply by being myself.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I'm not going to fall in love with you. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Okay. Nicely put. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I mean, I know myself. I'm not sure I even fall in love. Not like the way other people do. How's that for something to admit?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Well, like I said, Most Interesting Girl Award. AMANDA. I'm going to try to see that as a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You should. (putting on his coat and scart) Okay, se, this is refreshing. Utter honesty. Alright then, so you probably won't be hearing from me because even if you wanted to, which you clearly don't...I have the classic male problem of no follow through. Absolutely never remember to call after a date.... But... as this wasn't a date, I guess I'm off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (takes a sec...) But what if I wanted to call you? Amanda doesn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right. Well, if your flight is cancelled or you change your mind...I'm meeting some friends in (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: the pub in town tonight...and if not...then....Well...You're lovely. She crosses to him.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: So are you. They hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Canned Christmas music plays as Camera finds Amanda at th HEAD OF A LONG LINE OF PASSENGERS. She stands across the table from a Uniformed Guard in lat gloves routinely feeling around the edges of her open suitcase. She watches as he starts to unzip her make up b She CLOSES HER EYES and HEARS and SEES the trailer versio her life continuing.

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER GUY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: She wasn't looking for love. QUICK CUT —- AMANDA OPENING THE DOOR AND SEEING GRAHAM.

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER GUY'S VOICE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But that doesn't mean it didn't find her.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO REALITY
dialogues.text: Amanda realizes her suitcase has passed inspection. She moves along in line. cur TO:

dialogues.speaker: A BLACK SCREEN
dialogues.text: We hear fumbling then the BUZZ of the BLINDS BEING RAISED We’re in AMANDA'S BEDROOM IN BRENTWOOD. Iris just woke up As her eyes adjust, she sees her fantastic surroundings a huge smile crosses her face. She remembers she's happy. S hits a button on the Bose cD player on the night table an Aerosmith blasts through the reom. She begins to dance around while still lying under the covers. Her cell phone RINGS. She lowers the Music.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (cheerfully into phone) Hello.  47.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Where am I finding you?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (stunned, sobered) Jasper?

dialogues.speaker: JASPER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Is it okay that I'm calling you?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I guess... How are you?

dialogues.speaker: JASPER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Could we start with a less complicated question?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: {laughs but cautious) What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JASPER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: How long are you going to be there?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Two weeks. Why?

dialogues.speaker: JASPER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: I guess I can wait, but I'm having some real problems with this section of my book. I could use some Iris. (Iris starts to deflate) Would it be awful to send you some pages? Just tell me if it is. I don't want to mess you up but I know you're the only one who can help me.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Well, I mean, if you need me... Iris hits the BLACK OUT BUTTON again and the BLINDS start LOWER. As she SLOWLY GOES INTO DARKNESS, their conversati continues.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: You know you're my little survival kit. (Iris SIGHS) Now, honey, I want you to promise me you'll have fun today, okay?  48.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: (from TOTAL DARKNESS) Okay. I'll do my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pub is smoxy, noisy and packed too tight. Graham ENTE his face red from the cold, scarf around his neck. His ey scan the place for Amanda. She's not there. He hides his disappointment, then brightens when he finds his friends, COUPLE his age, at a table in the back. He joins his frie and orders a drink. His friend says something to make him laugh, which he does wistfully. As he takes off his scarf he looks up and sees Amanda through the crowd, sitting at bar, watching him. He breaks into a smile.

dialogues.speaker: BRENTWOOD STREET
dialogues.text: From the windshield of Amanda's Prius.

dialogues.speaker: GPS VOICE
dialogues.text: Turn left in 50 feet.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (imitating the voice) Thank you very much... IRIS drives, eating potato chips. She turns a corner and passes her elderly neighbor, Arthur, walking alone. He se dost. Iris drives past him slowly, looks at him in her re view mirror then backs up, gets out, approaches him. She speaks to him as if he's not only old but deaf.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but... may I offer you a lift home?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (matter of fact) Why? You know where I live?

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: I believe I do. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Good, then that makes one of us. Surprised by his sharpness, Iris opens the passenger door places Arthur's walker in the backseat then helps Arthur to the front seat. Iris runs back to the driver's side, jumps in, starts driving. Arthur removes something from h seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking it} oh, sorry. Movie Star map. I was sightseeing all day. Did you know Antonic Banderas, Goldie Hawn, Duetin Hoffman and Arnold Schwartzenedger all live within a mile of here?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: No, I did not.

dialogues.speaker: IRTS
dialogues.text: I don't know if it's true, but it's what the map said. I'm staying at the house right next door to you.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Which one? The brick monstrosity or the one behind the gates no one can see.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I'm in the one behind the gates.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Yeah? How is it back there?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Beautiful actually. This is you, right here, isn't it? Iris pulls into Arthur's driveway. He lives in a classic Spanish Hacienda with a neatly groomed lawn.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Had no idea I was so close.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Your house is quite lovely. Looks a little like Spielberg's house but...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: ~- Smaller? iRIS (laughs) Just a little.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I've lived here 47 years. Back then there were only 6 houses on this block. Every year, they tear (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: another one down...not that I blame them...they weren't great to begin with but that's how I got confused, didn't recognize one house.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: That would be confusing.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: What part of England are you from?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Surrey.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Cary Grant was from Surrey.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: That's right, he was. How'd you know that?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: He told me once. Well, I thank you very much young lady... Arthur can't find the door handle, keeps feeling for it.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: You are very welcome. Let me help you with that. Iris runs around to Arthur's side, opens the door, helps out, hands him his walker and escorts him up the path tow hie house.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Well, this was some meet cute.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: It's how two characters meet in a movie. Say a man and a woman both need something to sleep in and both go to the same Men's Pajama Department. The man says to the salesman, "I just need bottoms” and the woman says, "I just need a top". They look at each other and that's it. That's the meet cute. This isn't quite that cute, but...

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: So, you're in the film business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was. Yes I was. I was a writer. They've arrived at Arthur's FRONT DOOR. Arthur takes out key, his hand shakes as he tries to get it in the keyhole Iris watches as he repeatedly tries to insert the key.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I could be here 'til tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (snapping to) Oh. Sorry. Let me help you. Iris takes the key, opens the door and helps Arthur in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faded seventies decor. Iris peeks through the rooms, sees office with lots of books, a cluttered desk, an electric typewriter and sitting in front of a window, amongst asso knick-knacks -- a dusty Oscar. Stunned, Iris turns her attention back to Arthur who is slowly turning on a lamp.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Well... Um...Good-bye then. I enjoyed our meet cute.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I thank you for rescuing me.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Pleasure...absolutely. {notices a lousy looking dinner on a tray) You know...I hope you don't find this strange, but I've just arrived in town, don't really know anyone and I was thinking of going out to dinner tonight...if you're not busy, would you like to join me?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Busy? Honey, I haven't been busy since 1978.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iris and Arthur sit in a booth by the window, mid-meal. B are drinking beer.  52

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: So that was your first job in Hollywood? Louis B. Mayer's cffice boy? That's amazing.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Actually, my first job was as a Western Union messenger. That's how I met Mayer. I delivered a telegram to his office at MGM. When I walked in, the girls in the office were all in a tizzy...their office boy didn't show up and the boss was screaming. I volunteered for the jcb and the next day I was on the payroll. I was seventeen years old.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Wow. Then how long after that did you become a screenwriter?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Well, you gotta remember, there was no such thing as film school back then. You learned by being there. I met everybody working in Mayer's office -- all the big stars, the directors... But the ones who impressed me were the writers. They were witty, sophisticated guys with huge intellects... not to mention, they got all the great women. So I started writing and before long I was in the writer's building. They gave me a lovely office, a desk, a secretary, a big davenport. I never wanted to leave.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: So Hollywood really was as great back then as I imagine.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: It was better... (takes a good look at her) You know what I've been asking myself all night? Why would a beautiful girl like you go to a stranger's house for her Christmas vacation and on top of that, spend her Saturday night with an old cocker like me. That's gotta be a story.  53

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Oh, because I just wanted to get away from the people I see all the time.... Well, not all the people. One person... I wanted to get away from...one...guy....ome old boyfriend...whoe just got engaged... (her eyes fill up) and forgot to tell me...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: -. So, he's a schmick.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (laughs, wiping her eyes) As a matter of fact, he is. How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: He let you go. This is not a hard one to figure out. {Iris locks up surprised, her eyes still watery) Iris, in the movies, we have leading ladies and we have the best friend. You, I can tell, are a leading lady but for some reason, you're acting like the best friend.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (tearful) I've been in therapy for three years and my dector has never explained anything to me that well.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: You don’t live to be my age, without learning something. Arthur hands Iris his handkerchief. She wipes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, maybe one day while you're here, I'il take you for a drive and show you the old Hollywood. The one I knew.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Would you really? What about now? Bre you too tired?  54.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I haven't been out of the house at this hour in years. Now you want to go for a drive?

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Well, only if you want to.

dialogues.speaker: THE SUNSET STRIP
dialogues.text: Billboards for Gucci, iPod, Skyy Vodka. Bright and brash.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS DRIVES AMANDA'S CAR
dialogues.text: at a steady pace. Arthur sits next to her.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Okay, look up here on the right. That was The Trocadero. The swankiest. of the swank. Black tie every night. I first laid eyes on my wife right there. It was raining. She was standing under an umbrella in a satin dress the color of champagne. Iris LOOKS OVER at the SPOT where the Trocadero was and s AN EMPTY PARKING LOT next to Chin Chin. Arthur doesn't se To see the empty lot as he looks out at it and smiles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: All right, over here, that was Ciro's.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I've heard of that.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Anyone who was anyone went to Ciro's. They had a terrific orchestra. And great fights brceke eut at Ciro's. Every night ended with a black eye. It was tremendous. iris looks over and sees THE COMEDY STORE where Ciro's us to be.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, now, this place was owned by the great Preston Sturges.  55. Iris LOOKS OUT her window and sees MIYAGI'S a large JAPAN RESTAURANT.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It used to be called The Player's Club. He opened it in the summer of 1940 and if he felt like closing down for the night and just antertaining his cronies, that's what he did. To me, this was the hilt. Arthur stares up at the Player's Club and for a split sec SEES IT AS IT ONCE WAS: 1940's Packards and Caddies linin the curb and elegantly dressed Men and Women entering the front door. Tris looks over at Arthur. He realizes he's been day dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think that's enough, kid. I'm pooped.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Me too. They drive in silence. The neon bouncing off the windshie

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
