dialogues.text: On the way home, we'll take a little detour. I'll show you Bogart's house.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An early mist drifts over the snowy fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time it's Graham at the Coffee maker. He's wearing l night's clothes. He hears a loud CL y an "Ouch!!!" from the Bedroom and then Charlie skids out of the room. Then, Amanda STUMBLES IN, locking ship wrecked. She holds onto docr frame.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I haven't had that much to drink in... What am I saying? I've never had that much to drink.  56.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes... I believe no one ever has.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: The last thing I remember was coming in here last night and-- She spots her bra perched on a lamp shade. She shrieks, t looks up at Graham.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: T had nothing to do with that.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (embarrassed to death) But you were here.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (smiles) I was.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (pointing to bedroom) Then I guess we... (Graham shakes his head "no’) We didn't?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: We did not.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Thank God... I mean, act “thank God" but just thank God because I didn't remember doing it. All I remember is waking up to Charlie licking my toes.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Now that was me actually.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It was not!

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: No, it wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: {getting it straight) Was not.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Was not. I was...kidding. Obviously not very well.  57.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: So now why didn't we...? Can you remind me a little?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Amanda, call me old fashioned but one does not have sex with women who are unconscious.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Unconscious. Oh. That must've been attractive. Why did you stay?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Because you asked me to.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (remembering) Oh, I did. Didn't I? Oh, man...

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: From the moment I met you, it's been an adventure.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yes and I'm deeply sorry about that. I have nothing to say for myself other than, I must be temporarily nuts right now...it’s the holidays, I'm jet lagged ..I'm obviously still reacting to this break up or meeting you or... Graham's cell phone RINGS. It is on the table closest to Amanda. She picks it up, reads it.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Olivia. Sorry. I didn’t mean to look.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I should probably take this one. Graham very warmly says "Hello" as he EXITS OUT THE FRONT DOOR. Amanda WATCHES GRAHAM THROUGH THE WINDOW, talking o his cell in the FRONT YARD. He's laughing. Amanda can't help but feel a little jealous.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (to herself) Olivia. Sophie. Amanda... Busy guy... Amanda pours herself a cup of coffee as Graham RE-ENTERS.  58.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I think we should go into town.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I think you should get dressed, we should take a drive, get some lunch and get to know each other.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Really? Why?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Because I'm running out of reasons why we shouldn't. Aren't you? INT. RANGE ROVER -— MOVING - DAY Graham drives. The classic winter landscape of the Englis countryside whizzes by... a distant castle, rolling hills Amanda looks over at Graham, and unlike Ethan, he looks b and smiles. Their eyes connect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham and Amanda walk past the local shops. A Young Cami Parker-Bowles type passes carrying groceries.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (surprised to see him) Graham. .i

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: {not pausing as they pass her) Cynthia... Cynthia stops, checks Amanda out. Amanda and Graham pass by the BUTCHER SHOP. The YOUNG FEM BUTCRER can be seen THROUGH THE WINDOW. Both the Female Butcher and her OLDER FEMALE CUSTOMER turn to see Graham Amanda pass. Graham nods to them both. The Customer reach on her tippy toes to see them better. Amanda notices.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (explaining) very small village... Another Woman, Amanda's age, passes, pushing a toddler in stroller. .  59.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: (very friendly) Hey, look who's...

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes, how ‘bout that. The Toddler cranes her neck out of the stroller to watch them. Graham grabs Amanda's hand and quickens their pace. At a stoplight, a real Knock Out sits behind the wheel of Jaguar XK. She glares at Graham. He waves politely. She gives him the finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're back on the open road.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I have a much better place to take you.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Somewhere maybe a little less crowded?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Less crowded and also much more less crowded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Range Rover drives down a long country lane, brackete enormous oak trees. At the end of the lane, a quiet Count Estate turned COUNTRY HOTEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda and Graham sit across from one another in this idy spot. A fire crackles in the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: So... you're a book editor?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes I am.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: In London I presume?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I commute every day except when I'm actually editing, then I work at home. It's why I live out here, I (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: couldn't live in London any more and get things done. Too many distractions.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Seems to me there's no shortage cf distractions out here.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: That’s not entirely true.

dialogues.speaker: AMANTA
dialogues.text: So what kind of an editor are you?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: A very mean one.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: No, what I meant was, do you give massive notes or..?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Well, the better the writer, the less notes I have to give.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Right. And what did you study in schooi?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Literature.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Did you always know this waa what you wanted to do?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Okay, my palms are starting to sweat, I feel like I'm on a job interview.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I know. I'm interrogating you. I'm sorry. I haven't been on a first date in a long time.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Well, since we've already had sex and slept together twice, I think we can bend the first date rules. Why are you blushing?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I don't know. I think you make me nervous. I'm going to try to he (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes 61

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: myself with you...never easy, but I'm going to try. a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Ckay, we're doing well. Now what was the question? Oh, did I always know I wanted to be a book editor. The answer is... Yes I did. My family's in publishing. My father's a writer of historical fiction and my mother was and is to this day, a very important editor at Random House.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Wow. So you grew up with a busy, important, working Mom.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes I did. She's very formidable. May be the best there is at the job and doesn't let you forget it.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Are your parents still together?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: My parents are not only still together, they are still madiy in love. Hideously so.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Why hideously so?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Because, honestly, it borders on obscene. They're old and they've been spotted making out while walking the dogs. They call each other ten times a day. They set the bar very high when it comes to relationships and commitment which could explain my sister in love with a man who does not even appreciate her and of course, my disastrous romantic life. Okay, believe your time's up. Your turn.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Well, like I said the other night, I own a company that does movie advertising.  62

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I didn't realize you owned the company.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: That's because I probably didn't mention it but now that I know you were raised by such a strong working mother, I can say it and maybe you won't be intimidated by it.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: No, no, I'm still a little intimidated by it.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Well, "a little” is way ahead of the curve.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: What about your family?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: My parents broke up when I was 15. It was, at the very least...the defining event of my life. I'm an only child and I just didn't see it coming. We were very close, we used to call ourselves The Three Musketeers and then one night, after dinner, my parents sat me down and told me they were breaking up. I thought they were kidding, then I saw a suitcase out of the corner of my eye. In the hallway. My Dad moved out that night. I think I cried myself to sleep for months. Then I realized I had to toughen up so I refused to let myself cry. Sort of haven't cried since. I also haven't thought of that packed suitcase maybe ever.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You haven't cried since you were fifteen? Really?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I know it must mean something awful. I know. And I try but it's like something just permanently shut off in there. Anyway, my Dad's remarried and my Mom's still (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: single...of course but she's very strong. This has had its effect on me. Obviously. I'm still talking about it 17 years later... (rubs her chest) Can't we talk about you some more?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (bailing her out) Yes. Absolutely. Okay. Well...1 ery all the time.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You do not.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes Ido. I cry more than any woman you've ever met.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You don't have to be this nice.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I happen to be telling the truth. A good book, a great film, the opera... I more than cry. I weep. I'm a major weeper. It's pathetic, is what it is. Strangers have made fun of me... Amanda softens and as MUSIC BEGINS we DISSOLVE THROUGH TO REST OF TEE THETR MEAL, their conversation is lively and warm. DISSOLVE TO LATER and Graham moves his seat from ac the table to next to Amanda on the banquette. LATER, THEY WALK THE SNOW COVERED GROUNDS... sit on a snow covered hillside, lean back and kiss, the snow creating a blanket underneath them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rangé Rover pulls up to the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You're right. This was a great idea. (Graham TURNS OFF the car) You don't have to... walk me in... (he reacts) I mean, it’s freezing and...

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: -- You can just say you don't want me to come in.  64.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It’s not that, I'm just tired, I think I'm gonna take a nap and... (sees his reaction) It's not that.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll pretend I believe you.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Graham, I'm leaving in nine days and that makes this complicated and I'm not sure I can handle complicated right now. Graham nods. She kisses him. He holds back. She kisses hi again.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: And that doesn't make it complicated?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Sex makes everything complicated. Even when you don't have it, the not having it makes things complicated.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Which is why it's usually better to have it. -- Some say. (she laughs but doesn't bite) Okay, it's bloody freezing. He turns the car back on.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I know, I'm gonna sieep in my coat and possibly my boots...

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: We're back to being awkward with each other. Did you see this coming?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Graham, you're a book editor from London, I make trailers in L.A.. A long distance relationship would just baffle me but I do find you really attractive and sexy. Incredibly attractive and sexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, well, saying it twice helps. Well... I'm off to work in the morning. I promise I won't be drunkenly banging on your door any time soon.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Do IT have your number?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I'm in the directory.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Great. And you obviously have the number here. So, we'll see each other, okay? We'll figure something out.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Good. Amanda gets out of the car, shivers, making him laugh, th runs into the house. Graham sits there, thinking. HEAR a DOORBELL. AND A DOOR OPENS - IN L.A. And Miles is on the other side of it, holding a Fed Ex package.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Hello. Bad timing? Iris, on the other side of the door. Happy to see him.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: No, come on in. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: I'm good, I'm good.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: This Fed Ex was leaning on the gate. {reads it) From London, England.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: {opening the Fed Ex) Oh, a friend of mine is writing a (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: book and I give him notes sometimes. Inside the Fed Ex are about 20 typed pages with a NOTE CA paper-clipped on the front.

dialogues.speaker: THE NOTE CARD
dialogues.text: But the card is blank. Iris turns the card over. Also blank. Iris pales a bit then places the package on the table. Miles hears VOICES FROM THE KITCHEN.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You have company?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm having a little Chanukah party.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: What did you... join a temple since I last saw you?

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: My neighbor next door knew I didn't know anyone here so he wanted to introduce me to some of his friends... and...somehow it turned into a Chanukah thing. Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (following her in) Alright, I'm into the dreidel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and two of his friends, ERNIE and NORMAN, both aro 80, sit around the table. The men all look sharp. Marta, the Mexican Housekeeper makes latkes at the cooktop. Mile and Iris ENTER, the boys quiet down.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: This is Miles...

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Kendall.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Miles Kendall. Arthur Abbott.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (floored) Arthur Abbottit What a thrill to (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: meet you. I didn't know you lived around here.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: That's code for, you didn’t know I was still alive.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Not true. I absolutely knew you were alive, I just didn’t know you lived in the neighborhood. It's a privilege to meet you. 67. He heartily shakes Arthur's hand. Arthur notices the way looks at Miles.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: You going to join us?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Arthur, no... He's just here to pick up a laptop.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Actually I'd love to. I= mean if you have enough... Iris opens her mouth but Arthur answers.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: We've got plenty. Sit next to Iris.

dialogues.speaker: CHANUKAH CANDLES
dialogues.text: down to almost nothing. A good time is being had Miles is enthralled and refilling everyone's wine All the guys, including Miles are smoking cigars.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: -- Don't listen to them, they're nuts.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: So you're saying you weren't a ladies man?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Never. I married very young.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Yes, because he had the greatest girl in town and he had to marry her to take her off the market. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: by all. glasses.  Miles and 68.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone loved Marion. She was fun, smart as a whip, greatest laugh...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: What'd he sey? She had the greatest ass?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Greatest laugh!

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: Although her ass wasn't so bad either. Iris exchange a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: She had real gumption. She was the girl I always wrote... Iris is touched by that.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: What about you Miles..,you're a man about town, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: No, gents, I sadly, am not.. I'm just a one woman at a time kinda guy. I've been dating a beautiful actress for about eight months. I don't know what she sees in me but I know I'm the luckiest guy in the world to know her. Iris tries not to react. I mean, she hardly knows the guy

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Oh, she's an actress. What's she been in? Anything I would've seen?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: She hasn't done that much yet. She was a girl in the cafeteria in Mean Girls...a cigarette girl in The Aviator...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: And where is she tonight?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Lock - he’s half dead and still interested.  69.

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: He said, ‘cigarette girl'...I'm curious. He's with us... Where is she? Again Arthur takes note of Iris' interest.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: She's on location in New Mexico. Working on a little indy film. She'll be there for about 10 days.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Well, her loss is our gain. {looks at Iris looking at Miles) Fellas, I think we should leave these young folks and get back to our bedpans.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Norman, you're calling me for pinochle...

dialogues.speaker: NORMAN
dialogues.text: I got your cell. I'11 be in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iris opens the door for Miles who holds Ethan's lap top a some tin-foiled left overs.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Totally great night. You know, Arthur Abbott is maybe the last of the great Hollywood writers from that generation. There are like famous things we say...because he wrote them.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I knew. He told me his friends wrote Casablanca but he added the "kid" to “Here's looking at you, kid."

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Hello... Which totally makes the line.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Absolutely. "Here's looking at you, Ilsa"...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Not so memorable.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: He's so modest. He gave me this long list of eld movies I had to see...none written by him of course. I saw a couple today. They were fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Maybe we can see one together sometime.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: That would be .great. A warm wind from outside blows toward them.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Okay, s0...then, I'll call you. (kisees her on the cheek) The brisket was great....loved the latkes... Great hangin‘ with you... (kisses her on the cheek again) Sorry, didn't mean to kiss you twice. .

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: No problem. Miles exits, facing more wind.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Crazy weather.

dialogues.speaker: _ IRIS
dialogues.text: I know. vol Tris feels her cheek where Miles kissed her. she cLosps t DOOR, looks at JASPER'S PAGES, lifts them up, then oh Y her mind and places them back on the table. saad

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. AMANDA'’S LARGE, LUXURIOUS BATHROOM — MINUTES LATER Iris runs a bath. She locks at Amanda's assortment of Rat Producta: Anti-Stress Bath Oil, Stress Relief Sea dats, ' Stress Less Mineral Bath, Breathe Tranquil Bubbling Bath. Relaxing Bath Salts and Calming Body Cleanser. Tris pts © little in of each. :

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Thank you Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: HOT STEAMY WATER RUSHING OUT OF A TUB FAUCET
dialogues.text: A HAND turns it off. We are IN IRIS’ TINY BATHROOM. NIGHT Amanda lies in Iris' tiny tub. It's so small, it's impossible to stretch out in it. It's quiet. Then:

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I can handle complicated!?! God! I can be such an ass-hole.

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER GUY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Amanda Woods..!

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER GUY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: She pushed every guy away, every time. It's not will she ever change, but does she want to? Big SPLASH as Amanda gets out of the tub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mini Cooper pulls into the gravel drive of this beautiful, warmly lit house and parks. Amanda steps out, wearing 4" heels and a chic coat. She reaches into the ca for a bottle of wine, a baguette, and some gourmet goodie She heads toward the front door, gathering her strength. notices smoke coming out of the chimney.

dialogues.speaker: KNOCK KNOCK
dialogues.text: Amanda stands at the door. No one answers. She rings the bell, licks her lips, she’s a little nervous. She hears m coming from inside. Then, suddenly, there he is.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: answers the door, shirt tail out, hair a bit messed.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Surprise!

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes. It is. Hi. Graham eases the door closed so that nothing can be seen  72. behind him.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Hi. So, I was heme doing nothing and thinking of you and realized a little complication never hurt anyone and then I thought, maybe this isn't complicated at all and I thought how silly it was that we were each in our houses -- alone -- five miles apart and also, I wanted to apologize.... I really am sorry for not inviting you in this afternoon. I don't know what that was about exactly... (seeing him grow increasingly uncomfortable) -- but whatever it was, I thought I should get over it and try to... (realizes) You're... not alone are you?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Uk, no I'm not actually. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: No, don't be. I shouldn't've just... Oh. Man. (Graham looks pained) Seriously. Do not worry about this. Thie was just me being stupid. With that, the door OPENS UP A BIT and standing at Graham side is a precious FIVE YEAR OLD LITTLE GIRL.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: {in a loud whisper) Who is it Daddy? Amanda looks from the child to Graham.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: {also in a loud whisper) Daddy?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes, I am Daddy. Amanda, this is my daughter, Sophie. Sophis, this is a friend of mine, Amanda.  73.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I'm...fine, thank you. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Very well, thank you. Do you want to come in? With that the DOOR PUSHES OPEN EVEN MORE and an ADORABLE YEAR OLD GIRL, holding a blanket stands next to her siste

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE ONE
dialogues.text: Daddy, who is this?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: {lifts the little one into his arms) This is Amanda. Amanda, my youngest, Clivia.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (putting it together) Sophie and Clivia... Olivia extends her little hand. Amanda, stunned, shakes i

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Your hand is cold.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Sorry, I ama little cold.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: {nudges Graham) Dad...

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Sorry. Yes. Of course. Come in,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big Christmas tree with lots of kids ornaments sits in large, warm Living Room. A family lives here. Amanda ente a bit dazed by it all. Confused and starting to feel horrified, she looks around for a wife.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Can we still have hot chocolate, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: With baby marshmallows?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (whispers) Dad, take her coat.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes... May I?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Sure, thanks. (whispers) Are you married? Tell me fast.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: No... Amanda takes off her coat to reveal a drop dead gorgeous, cut, sexy dress. Olivia, Sophie and Graham just stare at her. Olivia giggles.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I know I'm a tad overdressed.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I ilove that dress. It's gorgeous.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: You look Like my Barbie!

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: (noticing the wine and goodies) Is that for us?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yes, but, sorry about the wine.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: He'll drink it, don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes, the idiot will drink it.
Sophie takes the wine and things from Amanda. The Girls d through the bag to see what she's brought.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispering) I apologize for not mentioning this earlier...

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You're... (spells) d-i-v-o-r-c-e-d? Amanda sighs. The Girls turn around to see what caused th reaction.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Amanda, are you by any chance at all into hot chocolate? The Girls look to her. Is she?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I'm totally into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Three Girls sit at the table as Graham fixes muge of chocolate, topping each mug off with tiny marshmallows. H very handy in the kitchen, very at ease. The girls artwor hangs ail over the cabinets.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (as he hands the little one a cup) Qlivia...it's hot, blow on it. Olivia immediately starts to sip it.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM/SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (at the same time) Blow on it!! Amanda watches how great they are together. Graham then hands a cup to Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You too, Soph.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: She has more marshmallows than me.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: No she doesn't, you each have five. (hands a mug to Amanda) You have five too. Graham takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: If only I ate carbs.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Hmmm?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Carbs? What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Oh, it‘s all the stuff I never eat because I don't want to get... (realizes how stupid it sounds} +..you know what? Who cares? I'm just gonna go for it. Amanda takes a sip, slurps up a marshmallow and gets a chocolate moustache. The Girls laugh.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (realizing this) What? Do I have something on my lip? {to Graham) I don't, do I? She takes another sip, purposely making it worse. The Gir crack up. Graham smiles, appreciating her humoring the ki Amanda wipes her mouth as Olivia climbs onto Graham's lap as she climbs on him, she places her hand on Graham's fac

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (unable to see) Comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: (wobbly holds her hot chocolate) Blow on mine...  77.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Do you think there's a chance you won't spill this on me? With that Olivia tips her hot chocolate and some of it sp on Graham's pants.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ahbhh..... Thank you, excelient timing. The Girls laugh.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Iwas a big spiller when I was a little girl.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: She's the worst. Olivia continues climbing on Graham.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Because she can't sit still. ouch.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: You were like me?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I was. I thought I was the biggest spiller ever.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Do you spill now?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Sometimes. Because sometimes you just can't help it. Right? She wobbly brings her cup to her mouth. Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Dad, do Mr. Napkin Head.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: No, no, we do not do Mr. Napkin Head for company.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: (bopping up and down on Graham's lap) Do it! Do it! Please?  78.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Cuch. Girls, calm down.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE /OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Please!!!

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: O-kay if you settle down, I'1l do it. Quickly. Olivia grabs him and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you for that...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: You're welcome. Now do iti

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Amanda, may I have your napkin, please? Amanda hands Graham her cloth napkin and he places it ove his head, covering his face. He then takes his glasses ou of his pocket and places them on his eyes, but over the napkin.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (giggling) Now smoke. Graham picks up a spoon and holds it like a cigarette, placing it in his mouth, but through the napkin and simul emoking. All the girls laugh. He scratches his head, coughs, every bit gets screams from the kids. He pulls of the napkin, a little humiliated. Everyone applauds.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Do it again}

dialogues.speaker: GRAKAM
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? It's horrible enough that I did it once. Amanda laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Amanda, guess what? I have dress up clothes in my room.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You do?  79.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: So do I. And we have a tent too. Do you want to see our tent?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Girls, we will not ask Amanda to crawl in the tent.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: (looking hurt) You don't like tents? INT. THE GIRLS BEDROOM — UPSTAIRS A large tent made out of blankets has been constructed between the girls twin beds. Amanda, Graham and the Girls stand in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: This is seriously cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Girls enter with ease. Then Graham enters, bent over, then Amanda enters, barefoot.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: (rushing out) Hold on...we need an extra pillow.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Lie down.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Okay... On the floor are blankets and pillows. Sophie enters with more pillow, hands it to Amanda. it's obvious the childre are enamoured with her.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: You can use my pillow.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Lie down.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Can you please stop being so bossy.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: Lie down please. Next to me.  BO. The four of them LIE DOWN SIDE-BY-SIDE INSIDE THE TENT. T grown ups lie together book-ended by the girls A small la lights the inside of the tent, giving it an amber glow. o the ceiling of the tent are stars and a moon cut out of construction paper. Everyone lies there silently for a be Sophie burps.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: SOHPHIE
dialogues.text: (giggles) Excuse me. Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (staring up) This is an exceptionally great tent.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (also staring up) Yeah, it's got something, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: It's cozy.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah... Whe cut out all the beautiful stars?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: We did.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: The Three Musketeers. Amanda reacts to that. Graham's hand rests next to Amanda He almost holds her hand but doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Amanda. .?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: You smell good.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Do I?  B81.

dialogues.speaker: LIVIA
dialogues.text: Yes. I love perfume but he won't let me wear it.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Because you already smell good. (to Amanda) So do you, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: But I'm older so I guess I'm allowed.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: (turns on her stomach and looks at Amanda, really up close) I like your eye shadow.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: And your lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks, it's new.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: What's it called? AMANDA. I think it's called Coral Shimmer. Olivia places her finger on Amanda's mouth, touches it th places her finger on her own mouth and rubs it on.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispers) Looks good on you. Sophie checks her out... Olivia smiles.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: You know if you wanted to sleep over, that would be okay...we could push our beds together and it can be really fun.  a2.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: That's so sweet of you to invite me but maybe ancther time...would that be alright?

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: {thinks about it) Yes. Olivia lies back down, touches Amanda's hand.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We never have grown ups here that are girls.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIA
dialogues.text: I really like it.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Me too. No one says anything as they all continue looking up at t construction paper stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda waits. Graham comes down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I can't imagine anyone making a bigger hit with my children. They want to play dress up with you, do your hair, wear your shoes. They're already imitating your léugh.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: They're great...

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Thank you. Sophie has unfortunately taken on the role as my protector. She's brilliant but I hate when she worries about me and Olivia's gonna be a real ball buster... which I must admit I love about her.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to figure out why you didn't tell me about them.  83

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (with difficulty) Because I just don't ever... tell women about them.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You think I should know your parents make out walking the dogs but not know you're a widower with two kids?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I was actually thinking of telling you earlier today, when we were having lunch.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: And. .?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Why didn't I? Right. Well, I don't know. Something strange seems to happen when women find out I'm a widower with two little girls...it's some kind of weird aphrodisiac and it messes me up...and with you, I really didn't want to play the “poor me" card.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: But it’s confusing since you're the one who wanted to go out to lunch to get to know each other...

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: (painfully explains) I have no defense except that until I know someone really well, it's easier for me to be just a normal single guy because it's way too complicated to be who I really am... because I am, in fact, anything Dut normal. I'm a full time Dad, I'm a working parent, I'm a mother and a father, I'ma guy who reads parenting books and cookbooks before I go to sleep. I spend my weekends buying tutus... I'm learning to sew. I'm on some kind of constant overload... So, I found it helps to compartmentalize my life, just until I figure this out. And so far, that's been alright... not that I see thet many (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: women, contrary to what you may think. This past weekend the girls were with their grandparents and when they're gone, I get to pretend I'm someone else. Someone without hot chocolate spilled on their trousers.... I don’t know how to date and be this. And there is the possibility that I'm petrified of what another person will do to who we are and how we get from one day to the next. I feel I'm a guy who can't make a mistake. Amanda takes that in and wonders if she would qualify as mistake.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: So I guess, given our weird thing, I sort of get you not telling me.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I didn't think I could introduce my kids to someone I may never see again.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Right. I'm just someone you had sex with once and slept with twice.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Actually I thought I was just someone you had sex with once and slept with twice. Neither one knows who's right.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I think we just went way past complicated.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Well, like you said, I'm a book editor from London...you're a movie trailer maker from L.A. We're worlds apart. I have a cow in the backyard.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: You have a cow?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Yes. I sew and I have a cow. How's that for hard to relate to?  85.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Pretty up there.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Exactly. Which I believe may disqualify me from winning bachelor of the month. They both wait for the other to say something to make thi better.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, anyway....thank you for being so sweet with the kids. I think it was eye opening for all three of us because they're absolutely right. We never do have grown ups here that ere girls.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I had fun....

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Good. Your visit may be the first step in pulling my odd little life together. So, really...thank you.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (not feeling so great) Glad I could help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham walks Amanda to her car. He's in his shirt sleeves she’s in her coat. Amanda turns to him:

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA,
dialogues.text: Graham...I'm glad I came over... Graham hugs her, holds her close, but doesn't kiss her. T moment is broken when from behind the house, they hear a

dialogues.speaker: GRABRAM
dialogues.text: Told ya... They break apart, Amanda smiles, hesitates, then gets in car. CLOSE on an UPSTAIRS WINDOW where Sophie watches Amanda d off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graham picks up some toys, turns out lights.  86. UPSTAIRS... He rounds the corner, picks up Olivia's littl socks and shoes then ENTERS HIS BEDROOM where Sophie lies his bed, under the covers.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Amanda's not going to sleep over is she?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Probably not.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHTE
dialogues.text: I was wondering what she would make us for breakfast. I bet it would be good.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Well, she's just here on vacation. I don't think we'li get a chance to find out.

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: Toc bad. You know why?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: SOPHIE
dialogues.text: I think she has potential.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: So do I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda, in her pajamas, dives into the cold bed. She lies there, under the duvet, tries to cry. She tries really ha Nothing comes. She gives it her all. Nothing. She checks her watch, reaches for her cell, dials, waits, then...

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: ~- Dr. Grinstein. Hi, it's Amanda. I'm in England. I know I should've called and told you I was leaving but it was all very last minute. I wanted to tell you, I met a guy. He's maybe a great guy. He's a widower and has two adorable little girls. He's really “different” and well, you know how I can be sometimes. How it's hard for me to “expose myself" as you say...well, with him, I'm fighting that, yet...I don’t seem to be doing any (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: better... Not that any of this actually matters 'cause I mean I can't be what he needs and we both know that and anyway, we sort of put the brakes on things tonight but.... you know how I said I never fall for "nice"... well, he's maybe the nicest guy I ever met. He's so nice, he's almost maternal. So you're right...all men aren’t schmucks. I had to come te another continent to find that out... Anyway, he's got his own stuff to work out but I do like him... He's very real and he's taking sewing lessons! How sweet is that? (beat) Okay, well, hope you get this message. You can try me back on my cell. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright beautiful day in Southern California. The Garden is clipping the roses. The front dcor opens and Iris exit

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (tc Gardener) Good morning, Jesus. Morning. The wind blows.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Santa Anas...

dialogues.speaker: JESUS
dialogues.text: {looking at the trees) Leng time now... Using the clicker, Iris opens the gate as Marta, the Housekeeper enters past her.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Hey, Marta.

dialogues.speaker: MARTA
dialogues.text: Buenas dias Iris. Iris reaches up and PICKS AN ORANGE off the Orange Tree. Iris sees the MAIL TRUCK at Arthur's, sccots over to it.  ge.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: {to Mailman ) I'll take it to him...

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Helloooo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is in his office, behind his desk, reading the Los Angeles Times with a magnifying glass. Iris ENTERS, holdi his meil.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (drops the paper) I counted. Nine movies are opening today. I remember when nine movies would open in a month. Half the movies I wrote would never have had a chance in today's world. Now a picture has to make a killing in the first weekend or they're dead. This is supposed to be conducive to great work? What if every book had to be read in one weekend or every painting had to be seen the day it was hung in the museum? Who knew movies would turn into a sporting event?

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Have you always been this feisty?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I may have slowed down a little, but yes. You gotta fight the fight, kid.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: {laughs} Can I open a window in here? It's very beautiful outside.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I don't think the windows open in here.  83. Iris tries to open one. It's difficult, but she manages t pry it open, then opens the next. She leans over Arthur's Oscar...touches it when he's not looking.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like that Miles by the way.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Yes, he's very nice.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: He's got eyes for you...

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: No he doesn't. He's got a gorgeous girlfriend. As he told you.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: And the first night she's out of town who does he go visit?

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: {rolls her eyes) He was picking up a laptop. Do you want your mall?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I'm just saying...a girl ona mission such as yourself may want to pay attention to a thing like that.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: {looks at Arthur's mail) Gas Company. Phone bill... You got a letter from The Writer's Guild of America West. Arthur takes a look at the WGA Envelope and tosses it in trash.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: You watching the movies T recommended?

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Yes. Love them. Irene Dunne is fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Gumption.  90

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Yes! Tons of it. Arthur, you don't want to open that letter you just threw out?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: No. They keep writing me about the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (teke it out of the trash) But it looks important.

dialogues.speaker: ARTEUR
dialogues.text: It's not. They want to do some kind of tribute to me, an evening with me...I don't know, it sounds God awful.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: What. do you inmean? That sounds brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Would you like to walk out onto a stage on a walker, looking a hundred years old and see eleven shnooks who showed up to see you? they can forget it. I mean, its very nice...one little old lady in the office probably just found out I'm still alive and said,’Ew, let's give him a night’. But no, I ain't fallin' for this. Now, what's up?

dialogues.speaker: ERIS
dialogues.text: i wanted to know if you wanted to take a little walk, but now I have a better idea.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: What? We should go for a jog?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Arthur, is anything wrong with you? I mean physically wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: ARTEUR
dialogues.text: No, I'm just plain old. Too old.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: So if you were in better shape, you'd do this Writer's Guild night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, at my age, you don't get in better shape.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: (referring to letter) May I? (opens it, skims it) "An Evening with Arthur Abbott." Arthur, they want tc do this soon. I bet with a little exercise, you could walk out there on your own and maybe I could go with you...as your date or something.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I would take you proudly, but darling, I'm not going. Anyway, how would you propose to get me in shape? Seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur and Iris are walking side by side in the pool. The reach one side.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Alright, we did it! Now back! Iris turns and keeps walking as Arthur slips under the wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur is on the recumbent bike. He's not peddling.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Now go!

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: {still not peddling) IT eam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iris and Arthur, in their sweats, are drinking orange jui When Arthur's not looking, Iris moves his walker to where can't reach it. thur finishes his juice and unbeknownst t him, walks perfectly to his walker.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Nice walking, kid.  INT. AMANDA'S BEDROOM — THAT NIGHT Iris sits in front of the laptop. We hear the English "You've Got Mail". Iris spots an e-mail from Jasper. She hesitates, sits up straight, braces herself, then opens i

dialogues.speaker: JASPER'S E-MAIL
dialogues.text: Who What Where When and me? Iris isn't quite sure how to answer that. Fortunately, th phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM'S VOICE
dialogues.text: So, are you ever coming home?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Hi!

dialogues.speaker: LONDON
dialogues.text: Graham sits in a windew seat. on the train going back hom after a day's work. A stack of Christmas presents sit nex to him.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: How's it going? You having fun?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I met e really nice guy.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: See. And you said you'd never... What's he like?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: He's really cute, he's funny, very smart, very successful, I feel good when I'm with him which is an entirely new experience and he's about 85 years old.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Come on...

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: You know I can pick ‘em. He’s my next door neighbor...or Amanda's next door neighbor...by the way, have you met Amanda yet?  93

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: Uh, yes, I have actually.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Oh, dear, can you hold? Call waiting. Be right back. Hold on, I really want to talk to you. Iris pushes the FLASH button.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone} Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda, on her cell, takes Charlie for a walk.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: {into phone) Iris, hi, it's Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Oh, hi, how are you? How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It's going great. How's everything with you?

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm loving it. Your house is amazing and still in one piece I might add. Oh, can you just hold for a sec, my brother is on the other line.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Graham?

Maybe we're trying to figure this out because it makes us feel good to feel this way... ‘Cause we both know, if you lived in L.A., we'd take months to get to this point so maybe the fact that I'm leaving in eight hours makes this far more exciting than it might really be. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: You're seriously the most depressing girl I ever met. I have another scenario for you.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Good. {rubs her chest which is beginning to hurt)

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I'm in love with you. Did she hear him right?

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I apologize for the blunt delivery...but as problematical as this fact may be... I am in love. With you. And I'm not feeling this because you're leaving. And not because it makes me feel good to feel this way, which, by the way it does, or did, before you went off like that. I can't figure out the math of this thing, I just know I love you. IJ can't believe how many times I'm saying it...and I realize I come with a package deal, three for the price of one... and my package perhaps in the light of (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: day, may not be so wonderful or one anyone even wants a part of other than me...but...1I know what I want...which is in itself a miracle and what I want is you. (she turns to him, he waits...) And you speechless at this moment is not exactly the reaction one dreams of.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: I wasn't expecting "I love you". Hold on. I'm trying to find the right thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I think if the scbvious response doesn't immediately come to you... then...well...we can just... We should just talk about something else. Like possibly what a complete ass I am. Amanda's chest tightens and hurts.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As I recall, you did promise me you wouldn't fall in love with me.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Sh-sh...

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I guess I just wasn't listening.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: (moving toward him) I never met a guy who talks as much as me... you say so much more...but could you just, for now...be quiet. Please. She kisses him deep and hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lunch time and this smail West side restaurant is packed. Miles and Iris are eating at the Sushi Bar. They deep in conversation and their bedy language suggests the have become close.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I don't know how I've never seen The Lady Eve before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanwyck was dazzling. So sure of herself.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: And sexy.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Really sexy. Every movie he’s told me to watch has a powerhouse woman in it.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You ever think maybe he's trying to tell you something. Miles cell phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I didn't, but now that you mention it... Miles isn't listening anymore. He's staring at his cell.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ~- What's the matter. Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: {staring at the phone) Maggie. That stops Iris cold.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello. Hi... I'm doing okay. You don't sound so... He covers his free ear, so he can hear. Iris tries not to listen, but can't help it. Miles gets flushed as he liste to Maggie's end of the conversation. Iris starts to sink.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maggie... I'm tied up for a bit... (Iris is relieved then Miles checks his watch) Well, what time could you be there? Alright, I'il meet you there as sooh as I can. He hangs up, looks at Iris, stunned. Iris waits.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She misses me.  116.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (ever the good girl) Ses. She came to her senses. Miles puts down his chopsticks, lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We should get our check.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: No, take your time. I can wait 'til you're done. You love the spicy tuna here... Miles steals a glance at his watch, looks for the waitres

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I'm fine. And if you need to go I can get this. Miles leans over, quickly kisses Iris on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You are the best.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Ha. Miles gets up, takes off. Iris sits alone, swallows hard. Looks around, anyone watching?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (returns, talking) No, that's not right. We're eating. I'm not going to leave you here alone. He sits back down but so doesn't want toe be there.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Miles, go.... I'll see you at the Writer's Guild tonight. I mean, if you can make it still.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I gotta get all the way to Beachwood but I'm gonna try to be there. Anyway, I'm bringing the music. I mean, I want to be there. I just don't know how long this is gonna take. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: It's all good. Don't worry.  117. Miles rises, kisses her on the head, exits. Tris fumbles her wallet, drops a bunch of change, picks it all up, cal for the Waitress. Sits alone.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER'S PAGES
dialogues.text: Iris picks them up and carries them up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iris falls onto the bed, looks outside, the trees are blo hard. She pushes the button to close the blinds and the r falls into darkness. She turns on the night table lamp, begins reading. The phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (into phone, hopeful) Hello. (sits up) Jasper? I'm just reading your pages. I hadn't forgotten, I've been busy, that's all. How are you? (laughs) Gee you sound far away. (he's getting to her} That's not true... stop...I meant to answer you. You sent me... What kind of surprise? No, T don't think I got it... (a little confused) Alright. I'11 look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iris rushes down the stairs, holding her cell.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: (into phone) I don't see a box or anything. Checking the kitchen now... (ENTERS KITCHEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in here... Okay, hold on, I'm gonna go check the gate. When did you send it? Iris OPENS THE FRONT DOOR and standing there, right befor her, is Jasper, in the flesh. He holds a small gift.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: I found your Christmas gift.  118

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: {floored) You've shown up at my door!

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Yes, I have. Iris throws her arms around Jasper, hugging him almost to hard. He kisses her. She holds back.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Why are... What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: I was just going to ask you that. How long have you been gone?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Just two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Feels like forever. Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Some house...

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Really...what are you doing here? I'm in shock.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: My publisher wanted me to "take some meetings"...

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: -- But you hate L.A..

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Not if you're here.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: {trying to digest this) How's... Sarah? Jasper shoots her a look. Almost a reprimand.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: She's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never did get a chance to talk to you about that...your engagement. I was surprised you never mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: I didn't know myself until the day before. Do we have to talk about it right now?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: No...but...

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: —_ What about something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iris opens a bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This place suits you.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Really...you look different to me here. Iris deesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Iris, look at me... (she looks up at him) I came here because I had to see you. Had to.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Jasper, I don't understand this. I mean, I was right there..for three years. Remember? Square peg...round hole.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: That's what you said to me once. That we weren't really right for each other. We were a square peg and a round hole...  120.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: I don't remember that. I just know I didn't like when you were gone. I also never checked my e-mail more, it was driving me crazy that I wasn't hearing from you. She can't believe this. He sounds like her. He takes her his arms.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't want to lose you. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Lose me? This is too confusing...

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: (pulls her to him) I know. C'mere...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie paces, in tears. Miles listens. It's getting dark outside.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: I screwed up. Didn't you ever screw up Miles? No, you probably never have. I made a mistake. TIT was stupid and impulsive...he was older and... Miles looks outside and sees the Olive Trees bending and stretching in the wind. Miles BEGINS TO HEAR Iris' MELODY his head. It fills the soundtrack.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- I wish you'd just say something. I mean, how many ways do I have to say it? He wasn't what I thought and I started thinking about you and hoping you'd forgive me... Miles looks at her. She stops right before him, looking v beautiful and vulnerable and open.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you Miles? Will you forgive me? Iris' melody fades.  INT. IRIS' BEDROOM - ENGLAND - 3 A.M. Graham is asleep. Amanda is awake...thinking about the da they were lying in the snow, kissing and laughing. She tu to Graham, his eyes open. She smiles faintly, apologetica INT. AMANDA'S LIVING ROOM ~ L.A. — SAME TIME It's dark outside and only a small light is on in the roo Iris and Jasper lie on the sofa, entwined. Iris gazes up him.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: This look in your eyes. This is what I was always looking for.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I've always looked at you like this.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: No you haven't. He kisses her and then slides his hand down her pants, un her panties and over her backside.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Obhhh... I remember this ass. He pulls her to him...by way of her ass. She blinks.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Ummm...

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: Can you remove your hand from my bottom. ..please? (He doesn't) Please. (he slips it out, she untangles) you know what? (laughs at herself) I never thought I'd say this, literally ~ never - but I think you were absolutely right about us. (he looks confused) Very square peg...Very round hole.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: You can‘t mean that.  122.

dialogues.speaker: TRIS
dialogues.text: The great thing is... (breaks into a smile) I actually do. And I'm about three years late in telling you this but nevertheless, some things need to be said. Jasper -- you did not treat me right. You broke my heart and you acted like somehow it was my fault...my misunderstanding... I was too in love with you to ever be mad at you so I just punished myself... But, Chbhh, I remember this ass somehow newly entitles me to say -- It's over. This twisted toxic thing between us is finally finished. And you really can't just waltz in here, on my great Christmas holiday and tell me I'm suddenly looking at you the way you wanted me to. Like T have just improved and qualified to be with you. I'm miraculously done being your Girl Friday. I got a life to lead, buddy...and I don't think you're in it... Now, I'm terribly sorry, but I've got to be somewhere really important and you've got to get the hell out. And anyway, do you think Sarah would appreciate us doing this? She's a nice person. She deserves better.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Honey, you've changed.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I know, I think what I've got is something slightly resembling gumption.

dialogues.speaker: A TOWN CAR SITS IN ARTHUR'S DRIVEWAY
dialogues.text: Iris, in a dress and heels, scoots around the Town Car an knocks on Arthur's door. Without hesitation, the door ope Arthur is standing there, ready to go, speech in hand. He wears his new suit, new glasses. He pauses when he sees h lovely Iris Looks.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Iris, you're a knock out.  123

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Thank you. And may I say, so are you?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Did I do my tie okay? I haven't worn one in so long.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (fixes it a little) It's perfect.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I like this Hugo Boss. He cuts a nice suit. I got you something. Arthur reaches inside and brings out a Box with a WRIST CORSAGE in it. Iris can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Forgive me, last time I had a date, this is what we did.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (slips it on) It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: If it's too corny or if it's gonna ruin your outfit...you don't have to wear it.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I like corny. I'm looking for corny in my life.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Nice line.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: It's all those movies...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (smiles, then) Ckay, let's do it. Let's get this embarrassment over with.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Arthur and Iris sit side by side.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Do not feel bad for me if only a couple of dozen people are there. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I‘m not exactly Quentin Tarantino. I don't even think people appreciate the old films anymore for the writing. It's the directors they remember. Plus it's the holidays...people are away...

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: Arthur, you gotta shut up. The Car slows down.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This it?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (to Driver) Stay here. We'll be out real fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iris helps Arthur through the fairly empty Lobby. A Young Film Student type approaches Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Abbott?

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: We're all ready for you. Two Attendants OPEN DOUBLE DOORS as Arthur takes Iris' ar and they head:

dialogues.speaker: INTO THE AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: As they ENTER, a packed room rises to it's feet. A few hundred people, of all ages, applaud as Arthur walks the center aisle toward the stage. Light bulbs flash. Arthur tightens his grip on Iris. She places her hand on his. He reaches the bottom of the stage. Another Attendant wai to help him up a small set of stairs. The room quiets. Arthur lets go of Iris. She smiles at him as his new esco takes his arm. Iris takes a seat in the front row, an empty seat next to her. Then, out of the loudspeakers, we HEAR ARTHUR'S THEM MUSIC. Upon hearing it, Arthur lets go of the Attendant's arm and climbs the stairs alone to a rounding swell of applause.  125. Miles, a little out of breath, slips into the seat next t Iris, wearing a coat and tie.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: The man is a rock star.

dialogues.speaker: IRTS
dialogues.text: (stunned) Hi...

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: (fxom the podium) Thank you. I'm absolutely overwhelmed... (then) --that I could climb those stairs. Laughter from the audience.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you very much for coming tonight. I am honored. I came to Hollywood over sixty years ago and immediately fell in love with motion pictures. And it's a love affair that's lasted a lifetime. When I first arrived there were no cineplexes or multiplexes. No such thing as a blockbuster. I was here B.c.. Before cable, before DVD, before conglomerates owned the studios, before pictures had special effects teams and definitely before box office results were reported on the nightly news. To make a good picture, all we needed was a girector, a producer, actors and a writer with a story to tell. our vocabulary was a simple one. Emotion, dreams, tears and laughter.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS AND MILES
dialogues.text: Their eyes on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: He's fantastic. Miles lcoks at Iris as she watches Arthur. eyes touches him. The warmth in her  They both himself.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Iris.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: (turns to him) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: What are you doing New Year's Eve?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: I'll be back home New Year's Eve.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Do you know, I've never been to England. Never been to Europe.

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: If I came over there, would you go out with me New Year's Eve?

dialogues.speaker: IRIS
dialogues.text: {smiles at him) I'd love to. Yeturn their eyes to the stage, Miles neds to Nice!

dialogues.speaker: ' HOUSE
dialogues.text: A Mercedes waits for Amanda. She exits the house in her shearling coat, red scarf, just like she arrived. Graham stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Okay, we're not gonna make this a bigger deal than it already is.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: No we're not.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: It's not like we're never going to speak or e-mail...or...

dialogues.speaker: GRABAM
dialogues.text: No set rules.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: None. So, I'm just going to kiss you, for the millionth time and (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: say.... be seeing you. (she kisses him) Be seeing you.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: {moves her hair out of her eyes) Take care of yourself. Amanda walks to the car, waves, gets in and the car takes off. Graham watches the car drive slowly away from the cottage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Driver who dropped Amanda here two weeks ago is behin the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Have a good holiday, Miss?

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah....great. Maybe the best ever. Suddenly very hot, Amanda pulls her scarf off. She looks the car window. Children pass by, laughing on a sled. Who She's really hot. She unbuttons her coat a little. Clears her throat, checks her plane ticket, passport, phone. All set. Then, she clicks opens her phone, looks at the Photo herself with Graham. Closes the phone. She rests her head on the seat...doesn't feel quite right. What's going on? She's a little out of breath. Without knowing, without trying, with no effort whatsoever, her eyes begin to well Amanda sits straight up, stunned. Is it going to happen? Then, one small tiny little tear makes its way out of her and rolls down her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: TRAILER GUY'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Amanda Woods! Welcome back! Amanda screams. She tries to make herself cry, just to ge it all out. But all she can make is one more tear. She's thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Turn around! ‘urn around and go back! Pleasei!!

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Forget something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car turns around and takes off back toward the cottag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda is so excited, she's about to leap out of the movi car.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Can you go any faster?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: This little lane is always tricky...gonna take a bit...

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: That's okay... Amanda opens the car door, rushes out and runs, a happy, expectant leok on her face. She gets to the cottage, open the little gate, rushes up the stairs, opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Graham? She doesn't see him at first.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Graham? Graham, back in the bedroom, steps into view. He wipes aw tears. Amanda says nothing. Graham waits.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (from the Living Room) Iwas just thinking. Why would I leave before New Year's Eve? That makes no sense at ail. raham sighs quite loudly. Wipes his eyes on his shirt sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean you didn't exactly ask me out but you did say you love me so I'm thinking I've got a date...if you'll have me.

dialogues.speaker: GRAHAM
dialogues.text: I've got the girls New Year's Eve.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA
dialogues.text: Sounds perfect!  129. Graham smiles and as Amanda rushes to him, we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olivia, in a party dress and carrying a noise maker, runs through the room. She is followed by her Aunt Iris, also a party dress. Iris dances a bit as she carries two glass of champagne. She delivers one glass to Miles who is sitting on the sofa, deep in conversation with Sophie. He smiles when he sees Iris. Amanda dances in with a tray of hors d'oeuvres. She stops front of Graham who twirls her. Amanda then dances over t Iris who takes an hors d'oeuvre and the two women connect Amanda whispers something to Iris and Iris laughs. Graham joins them and puts his arm around his sister. Iris rests her head on his shoulder. Feels like the makings of a gre party. Camera pulls back and away, out the window and eventually we Fade to Black.
